pma:database.name: wacky_montana
pma:database.pma:table: CREATE TABLE `wp_cpwgp4_posts` ( `ID` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT, `post_author` bigint(20) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0', `post_date` datetime NOT NULL DEFAULT '0000-00-00 00:00:00', `post_date_gmt` datetime NOT NULL DEFAULT '0000-00-00 00:00:00', `post_content` longtext NOT NULL, `post_title` text NOT NULL, `post_category` int(4) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0', `post_excerpt` text NOT NULL, `post_status` varchar(20) NOT NULL DEFAULT 'publish', `comment_status` varchar(20) NOT NULL DEFAULT 'open', `ping_status` varchar(20) NOT NULL DEFAULT 'open', `post_password` varchar(20) NOT NULL DEFAULT '', `post_name` varchar(200) NOT NULL DEFAULT '', `to_ping` text NOT NULL, `pinged` text NOT NULL, `post_modified` datetime NOT NULL DEFAULT '0000-00-00 00:00:00', `post_modified_gmt` datetime NOT NULL DEFAULT '0000-00-00 00:00:00', `post_content_filtered` text NOT NULL, `post_parent` bigint(20) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0', `guid` varchar(255) NOT NULL DEFAULT '', `menu_order` int(11) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0', `post_type` varchar(20) NOT NULL DEFAULT 'post', `post_mime_type` varchar(100) NOT NULL DEFAULT '', `comment_count` bigint(20) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0', PRIMARY KEY (`ID`), KEY `post_name` (`post_name`), KEY `type_status_date` (`post_type`,`post_status`,`post_date`,`ID`), KEY `post_parent` (`post_parent`) ) ENGINE=MyISAM AUTO_INCREMENT=604 DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8;

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: Dylan met me at my shop in Belmont in the early afternoon, and we ran some errands and took care of some last minute stuff while waiting for Scott to get off work and roll down from SF. Unfortunately, work was insane for Scott and we didnâ€™t hit the road until well after 5pm instead of 3:30 or 4pm like weâ€™d hoped. We finally took off across the San Mateo Bridge and up to 580E through Stockton to Hwy 88. We ended up just past Pine Grove, CA around 9pm and found a campsite at Indian Grinding Rock State Historical Park. After setting up camp, we rolled back down to Pine Grove to see if we could still get dinner at the 88 Giant Burger in town only to find that it had just closed. I rolled in first and asked the kid lingering at the pickup window if the place was still open, to which he replied â€œno.â€ I asked what else might be open in Pine Grove where we could get a bite to eat and he said â€œnot this place.â€ I politely explained that I understood that the burger place was closed by this point in the coversation, but that we still needed to eat. With that, he recommended the â€œhot pocket storeâ€ down the street that was open until 11. Of course, â€œhot pocket storeâ€ is white-trash methhead language for â€œgas station convenience store,â€ so we ended up rolling back down 8 miles into Jackson to another burger joint for mediocre burgers and a $5 pitcher of Bud Light. Route Map [gallery]
Day 1: Bay Area to Pine Grove

Route Map [gallery]
Day 1: Bay Area to Pine Grove

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: In the morning, we rolled out of our Grinding Rock campsite and up Hwy 88 over Carson Pass, stopping for lunch in Kirkwood along the way. After lunch we rolled over the pass and down into Nevada, stopping for gas and refreshments outside Carson City, and taking a picture of the enormous moth that would be a harbinger of the insect storm to come. We didnâ€™t want to take 80 via Reno because 395 between Carson City and Reno are nothing but extreme heat, stop-and-go traffic and exhaust fumes. Instead, my route had us taking Hwy 50 from Carson City all the way out to Fallon, but on the fly I decided to cut up to 80 at Fernley, which turned out to be a good idea. Once we hit the 75mph speed limit on 80, we made very good time to Winnemucca. The ride was straight, flat, and hot as blazes as expected, but at least we were burning miles quickly. Unfortunately, we were also burning daylight quickly and, as we took 95 up into eastern Oregon, we watched the sun quickly setting to our left. At our next gas stop we had to make a command decision. We had some Hot Springs deeper in Oregon recommended by one friend, and a campground on the border recommended by another, but it was apparent that we weren't going to come close to making either by nightfall, so we opted to ride into the night and just get a motel room outside Boise to make up the time and mileage we lost on Friday night. We rode well into the night, being as paranoid as possible about animals on the road, and sailing through an absolutely insane monsoon of insects along the Oregon/Idaho border. We stopped for dinner at a Shari's (the only thing that was open) on the outskirts of Boise and I went ahead and made the first potato joke of the week, commenting on how incredibly fresh Shari's waffle-cut fries were. We ended up settling in at a Motel 6 on the other end of Boise (by the airport) and sleeping like logs. Route Map [gallery]

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
We packed up our bikes in the Motel 6 parking lot and hit the road toward the Sawtooth Mountains. The ride up was beautiful and twisty, and the roads were fairly smooth and well maintained. There were plenty of cars and bikes on the road, but we weren't really held back and had plenty of opportunities to pass for the most part.
We stopped for lunch in Stanley, Idaho and got horrible service from a very personable waiter. Dylan and I got our food finally, but Scott's club sandwich sat on the counter for a good ten minutes while he watched us eat. Eventually, I got up and told another waitress I was going to take the food so we could eat and get out of dodge.
Getting geared up to leave, we spoke to a husband and wife touring on an FZ1 and SV650 respectively, as well as our first of many groups of helmetless riders on their way to Sturgis. Everyone was extremely friendly no matter what type of ride they were on.
The cruise south from Stanley was mostly flat farmland, and not nearly as interesting as I expected. We stopped in Sun Valley for gas and a rest, and eventually ended up at Craters on the Moon National Park before sunset. We acquired our campsite and set up our tents, then Scott and I flew into the nearest town (Arco, ID) for beer and snacks while Dylan finished setting up camp and explored a couple of the volcanic caves in the park.
Night fell, but the moon didn't come up until well into the wee hours of the morning. We passed a few hours drinking and playing dominoes while listning to Patton Oswalt and David Cross albums on my iPod. I won with 300 points, Dylan had 205 and Scott took (it) up the rear with 190.
[gallery]

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: We woke up and packed up camp under the already-sweltering sun, without a lick of shade for 100 miles in any direction. Before hitting the road, we decided to take some time riding around the park and exploring a few of the cool volcanic formations. We spent a bit of time looking through some of the lava cones, and Scott and Dylan hiked to the top of one of the huge hills of black rock. I was profoundly lazy and hid under the shade of a parked RV rather than hiking up a hill in the sun wearing 50 lbs. of black leather. On the way out of the park, we asked the ranger at the gate about taking Hwy 93 up through eastern Idaho instead of taking I-15 up into Montana. He confirmed that 93 was more scenic, and told us it followed the Salmon River. From past experience, the three of us knew that any road that follows a river or creek is generally good, so we went with the new route. The first leg of 93 was flat and boring as expected--we were still in the agricultural (relative) lowlands of southern Idaho, but we had mountains in front of us and were looking forward to riding in them. We stopped for a ridiculously large lunch in Challis, ID where our AAA map said the scenic part of the road started. As promised, 93 from then on was beautiful. The roads were in excellent shape, and there was almost no one on the road. We hauled some fairly respectable ass. Once we crossed the border the speed limits went up significantly and so did our pace. With the glorious Montana speed limits, we were also met with a veritable ton of road construction, including quite a few stretches of nasty oiled gravel. We made good time between constructions zones, but were often held up for 10-15 minutes a pop when we hit another work site, and then a lot more time cruising over the gravel at 5mph. We cruised into Missoula, MT at dusk and stopped at the Walmart for some supplies, then decided to cut out to 93 via Hwy 200 and look for camping at Salmon Lake or Placid Lake. We ended up settling in at Salmon Lake, which had running water, hot showers and a firewood dispenser that resembled a gigantic, wooden coke machine. We put in 16 quarters and got a dry bundle of tiny logs that weighed about 3 ounces. Unfortunately, it took us four $4 bundles of balsa to realize that a neighboring (empty) campsite had a pile of huge, heavy logs that would probably burn all night, but we pilfered a few of them anyway to keep the fire going. Most campsites have an entry fee that covers 1 vehicle, and an additional vehicle fee for extra cars. Salmon Lake was $15 for the site, and appeared to be an additional $5 for every vehicle. Like we did at the campsite in Pine Grove, CA, we put cash for the site and 1.5 cars (6 wheels/3 bikes) in the self-pay envelope and waited to see if a ranger would hassle us in the morning. I was the first one up the next morning and, sure enough, a ranger rolled up like clockwork to (presumably) give us grief for not paying for 3 full vehicles. Instead, the ranger walked right up to me, handed me $8 back, and told me that the camp fee included all our vehicles. Gotta love Montana. Route Map [gallery]
Day 4: The Moon to Salmon Lake

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: I managed to get up a bit earlier than Deeter and Dylan and pack up all my crap, thinking I'd get a head start and get to relax and enjoy my bottle of Starbucks Dark Mocha Frapachino(tm) while they did their packing. Unfortunately, as I finished loading up my bike and the guys got up, I realized that my iPod was missing and probably rolled up in to my tent I un-bungeed all the stuff off my bike and rolled out my tent, only to find that it wasn't there. I eventually found it rolled up in my sleeping bag, so I ended up having to repack the TWO biggest pains in the ass of all my gear. Good times. We left camp sometime after 10am and cruised the rest of the way up 83 to a gas station in Bigfork, MT just outside of Kalispell. Up to this point, we'd been running either far behind or far ahead of schedule nearly every day, and we never had an idea of exactly where we were going to land until the sun started to decend. Matthew (MeterMan on BARF) had graciously offered crash space at his house in Kalispell, but at this point it looked like we would be rolling through Glacier in a couple of hours and end up far past Kalispell and somewhere down near Lolo by the end of day. I called Matt from Bigfork (just outside Kalispell) around 11:30am hoping to catch lunch with him on the way up to Glacier or possible an early dinner or drinks on the way out in the late afternoon. He had to work until 3:30ish, so it looked like it would be the latter. We pressed on up toward Glacier and stopped at a diner in Hungry Horse, MT (just outside Glacier) for brunch. After some epic pancakes, we pressed on to the gates of the park. Rolling in, Glacier was just as spectacular as I remember it 15+ years ago. We cruised in behind a bunch of RVs and SUVs as expected, and stopped at a river to take a few photos. When we started climbing up the aptly-named Going to the Sun Road, it became apparent that there was some heavy road construction going on inside the park too. About halfway up the mountain we hit more gravel roads, but this time steep and winding. I felt pretty hard-core riding a heavy (and heavily loaded) sportbike up this road on gravel, until I saw a couple riding 2-up down the mountain on a big ST1300. Evidently, we were pansies. We stopped several times for pictures on the way up, and a few times at one-lane construction corridors while oncoming traffic was allowed through. At one stop, we met a couple from Oakdale, CA on their way to Sturgis, one of whom was on a crazy customized "Bull Bike" complete with horns, a tail and nards, so of course Dylan got a picture sitting on it. Nice folks. Because of the construction, it ended up taking all day to get through Glacier, but the park was startlingly beautiful and well worth blowing the whole day. Coming down the backside on Hwy 89 around 6pm, the traffic finally cleared up a bit, and we were booking along at freeway speeds again. The speed limit was 70mph (as it is on most Montana backroads) and I was leading at about 90mph after just passing a car. By previous Montana construction experience, keen observation, or just by dumb frigging luck, I noticed that the road ahead suddenly got lighter in color, and that there was no center-line anymore. I assumed the worst and braked hard, rolling onto gravel at about 40mph just as I let off the front brake. To add insult to injury, the crew had placed a "Pavement Ends" sign several hundred feet past the start of the gravel. Thanks, guys. All three bikes stayed up, but we were not happy campers at all, given absolutely no warning before we potentially lost our shit. This construction zone stretched for 10 or 15 miles, and it took us forever to get to Browning (and cell reception) to call Matt again. We were still 100 miles shy of Kalispell and the sun was going down, so I called Matt and took him up on his offer for crash space after all. We did our best to follow the roads that AAA called "scenic" on their maps (the ones with the little green dots along the road), and avoid the ones that weren't deemed scenic. So far it had worked out fairly well, but Hwy 2 back to Kalispell was not marked as scenic and turned out to be fantastic. Riding carefully and watching for all the animals that tend to come out at dusk, we cruised back into Kalispell and eventually found Matt's house. It was pushing 9pm and hot as hell, so we ordered a couple of pizzas and started to decimate the case of cold Kokanee in Matt's fridge. It became quickly apparent that 12 bottles wasn't going to do the job, and that we were drinking him out of house and home. Matt and I made a quick trip to the local Hot Pocket Store(tm) for a couple more cases, and the rest of the evening was spent eating, drinking, and conversating over a thousand beers. Excellent times, and just what we needed. Route Map [gallery]

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: We woke up and packed up camp under the already-sweltering sun. Before hitting the road, we decided to take some time riding around the park and exploring a few of the cool volcanic formations. We spent a while looking through some of the lava cones, and Scott and Dylan hiked to the top of one of the huge hills of black rock. On the way out, I asked the ranger at the gate about taking Hwy 93 up through eastern Idaho instead of taking I-15 up into Montana. He confirmed that 93 was more scenic, and told us it followed the Salmon River. From past experience, all three of us knew that any road that follows a river or creek is generally good, so we went with the new route. The first leg of 93 was flat and boring as expected--we were still in the (relative) agricultural lowlands of southern Idaho, but we had mountains in front of us and were looking forward to riding in them. We stopped for lunch in Challis, ID where our paper map said the scenic part of the road started. As promised, 93 from then on was beautiful. The roads were in excellent shape, and there was almost no one on the road. We hauled some fairly respectable ass. Once we crossed the border the speed limits went up significantly and so did our pace. With the glorious Montana speed limits, we were also met with a metric ton of road construction, including quite a few stretches of nasty oiled gravel. We made good time between constructions zones, but were often held up for 10-15 minutes a pop when we hit another work site, and then a lot more time cruising over the gravel at 5mph. We cruised into Missoula, MT at dusk and stopped at the Walmart for some supplies, then decided to cut out to 93 via Hwy 200 and look for camping at Salmon Lake or Placid Lake. We ended up settling in at Salmon Lake, which had running water, hot showers and a firewood dispenser that resembled a gigantic, wooden coke machine. We put in 16 quarters and got a dry bundle of tiny logs that weighed about 3 ounces. Unfortunately, it took us four $4 bundles of balsa to realize that a neighboring (empty) campsite had a pile of huge, heavy logs that would probably burn all night, but we pilfered a few of them anyway to keep the fire going. Most campsites have an entry fee that covers 1 vehicle, and an additional vehicle fee for extra cars. Salmon Lake was $15 for the site, and appeared to be an additional $5 for every vehicle. Like we did at the campsite in Pine Grove, CA, we put cash for the site and 1.5 cars (6 wheels/3 bikes) in the self-pay envelope and waited to see if a ranger would hassle us in the morning. I was the first one up the next morning and, sure enough, a ranger rolled up like clockwork to (presumably) give us grief for not paying for 3 full vehicles. Instead, the ranger walked right up to me, handed me $8 back, and told me that the camp fee included all our vehicles. Gotta love Montana. Route Map
Day 4: The Moon to Salmon Lake

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
Dylan met me at my shop in Belmont in the afternoon, and we waited for Scott to get off work and roll down from SF. Unfortunately, work was insane for Scott and we didnâ€™t hit the road until well after 5pm instead of 3:30 or 4pm like weâ€™d hoped. We finally took off across the San Mateo Bridge and up to 580E through Stockton to Hwy 88. We ended up just past Pine Grove, CA around 9pm and found a campsite at Indian Grinding Rock State Historical Park.
After setting up camp, we rolled back down to Pine Grove to see if we could still get dinner at the 88 Giant Burger in town only to find that it had just closed. I rolled in first and asked the kid lingering at the pickup window if the place was still open, to which he replied â€œno.â€ I asked what else might be open in Pine Grove where we could get a bite to eat and he said â€œnot this place.â€
I politely explained that I understood that the burger place was closed by this point in the coversation, but that we still needed to eat. With that, he recommended the â€œhot pocket storeâ€ down the street that was open until 11. Of course, â€œhot pocket storeâ€ is white-trash methhead language for â€œgas station convenience store,â€ so we ended up rolling back down 8 miles into Jackson to another burger joint for mediocre burgers and a $5 pitcher of Bud Light.
[gallery]
Day 1 (Night, actually.): San Francisco to Pine Grove

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
In the morning, we rolled out of our Grinding Rock campsite and up Hwy 88 over Carson Pass, stopping for lunch in Kirkwood along the way. After lunch we rolled over the pass and down into Nevada, stopping for gas and refreshments outside Carson City, and taking a picture of the enormous moth that would be an omen for the insect storm to come.
My route had us taking Hwy 50 from Carson City all the way out to Fallon, but on the fly I decided to cut up to 80 at Fernley, which turned out to be a good idea. We didnâ€™t want to take 80 via Reno because 395 between Carson City and Reno are nothing but extreme heat, stop-and-go traffic and exhaust fumes.
Once we hit the 75mph speed limit on 80, we made very good time to Winnemucca, but we were still burning daylight quickly. We took 95 up into eastern Oregon and watched the sun setting to our left. At our next gas stop we had to make a command decision. We had some Hot Springs deeper in Oregon recommended by one friend, and a campground on the border recommended by another, but it was apparent that we weren't going to come close to making either by nightfall, so we opted to ride into the night and just get a motel room outside Boise to make up the time and mileage we lost on Friday night.
[gallery]

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: In the morning, we rolled out of our Grinding Rock campsite and up Hwy 88 over Carson Pass, stopping for lunch in Kirkwood along the way. After lunch we rolled over the pass and down into Nevada, stopping for gas and refreshments outside Carson City, and taking a picture of the enormous moth that would be an omen for the insect storm to come. We had some Hot Springs deeper in Oregon recommended by one friend, and a campground on the border recommended by another, but it was apparent that we weren't going to come close to making either by nightfall, so we opted to ride into the night and just get a motel room outside Boise to make up the time and mileage we lost on Friday night. Route Map [gallery]

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
We packed up our bikes in the Motel 6 parking lot and hit the road toward the Sawtooth Mountains. The ride up was beautiful and twisty, and the roads were fairly smooth and well maintained. There were plenty of cars and bikes on the road, but we weren't really held back and had plenty of opportunities to pass for the most part.
We stopped for lunch in Stanley, Idaho and got horrible service from a very personable waiter. Dylan and I got our food finally, but Scott's club sandwich sat on the counter for a good ten minutes while he watched us eat. Eventually, I got up and told another waitress I was going to take the food so we could eat and get out of dodge.
Getting geared up to leave, we spoke to a husband and wife touring on an FZ1 and SV650 respectively, as well as our first of many groups of helmetless riders on their way to Sturgis. Everyone was extremely friendly no matter what type of ride they were on.
The cruise south from Stanley was mostly flat farmland, and not nearly as interesting as I expected. We stopped in Sun Valley for gas and a rest, and eventually ended up at Craters on the Moon National Park before sunset. We acquired our campsite and set up our tents, then Scott and I flew into the nearest town (Arco, ID) for beer and snacks while Dylan finished setting up camp and explored a couple of the volcanic caves in the park.
Night fell, but the moon didn't come up until well into the wee hours of the morning. We passed a few hours drinking and playing dominoes while listning to Patton Oswalt and David Cross albums on my iPod. I won with 300 points, Dylan had 205 and Scott took (it) up the rear with 190.
[gallery]

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: I managed to wake up a bit earlier than Deeter and Dylan to pack up all my crap, thinking I'd get a head start and get to relax and enjoy my bottle of Starbucks Dark Mocha Frapachino(tm) while they did their packing. Unfortunately, as I finished loading up my bike and the guys got up, I realized that my iPod was missing and probably rolled up into my tent I un-bungeed all the stuff off my bike and rolled out my tent, only to find that it wasn't there. I eventually found it rolled up in my sleeping bag, so I ended up having to repack the TWO biggest pains in the ass of all my gear. Good times. Up to this point, we'd been running either far behind or far ahead of schedule every day, and never had an idea of exactly where we were going to land. We left camp sometime after 10am and cruised the rest of the way up 83 to a gas station in Bigfork, MT just outside of Kalispell. Matthew (MeterMan on BARF) had graciously offered crash space at his house in Kalispell, but at this point it looked like we would be rolling through Glacier in a couple of hours and end up far past Kalispell and somewhere down near Lolo by the end of day. I called Matt from Bigfork around 11:30am hoping to catch lunch on the way into Glacier or possible an early dinner or drinks on the way out in the late afternoon. He had to work until 3:30ish, so it looked like it would be the latter. We pressed on up toward Glacier and stopped at a diner in Hungry Horse, MT (just outside Glacier) for brunch. After some epic pancakes, we pressed on to the gates of the park. Rolling in, Glacier was just as spectacular as I remember it 15+ years ago. We cruised in behind a bunch of RVs and SUVs as expected, and stopped at a river to take a few photos. When we started climbing up the aptly-named Going to the Sun Road, it became apparent that there was some heavy road construction going on inside the park too. About halfway up the mountain we hit more gravel roads, but this time steep and winding. I felt pretty hard-core riding a heavy (and heavily loaded) sportbike up this road on gravel, until I saw a couple riding 2-up down the mountain on a big ST1300. Yeah, we were pansies. We stopped several times for pictures on the way up, and a few times at one-lane construction corridors while oncoming traffic was allowed through. At one stop, we met a couple on their way to Sturgis, one of whom was on a crazy customized "Bull Bike" complete with horns, a tail and nards, so of course Dylan got a picture sitting on it. Because of the construction, it ended up taking all day to get through Glacier. Coming down the backside on Hwy 89 around 6pm, the traffic finally cleared up, and we were booking along at freeway speeds again. The speed limit was 70mph (as it is on most Montana backroads) and I was leading at about 90mph after just passing a car. By previous Montana construction experience, keen observation, or just by dumb frigging luck, I noticed that the road ahead suddenly got lighter in color, and that there was no center-line anymore. I assumed the worst and braked hard, rolling onto gravel at about 40mph just as I let off the front brake. To add insult to injury, the crew had placed a "Pavement Ends" sign several hundred feet past the start of the gravel. All three bikes stayed up, but we were not happy campers at all, given no warning before we potentially lost our shit. This construction zone stretched for 10 or 15 miles, and it took us forever to get to Browning and call Matt again. We were 100 miles shy of Kalispell and the sun was going down, so I called Matt and took him up on his offer for crash space after all. We did our best to follow the roads that AAA called "scenic" on their maps (the ones with the little green dots along the road), and avoid the ones that weren't deemed scenic. So far it worked out fairly well, but Hwy 2 back to Kalispell was not one of them and it turned out to be awesome. Riding carefully and watching for all the animals that tend to come out at dusk, we cruised back into Kalispell and eventually found Matt's house. It was pushing 9pm and hot as hell, so we ordered a couple of pizzas and started to decimate the case of cold Kokanee in Matt's fridge. It became quickly apparent that 12 bottles wasn't going to do the job, and that we were drinking him out of house and home. Matt and I made a quick trip to the local Hot Pocket Store(tm) for a couple more cases, and the rest of the evening was spent eating, drinking, and conversating over a thousand beers. Route Map

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: Wednesday the 30th brought us our second nugget of excitement, after the high-speed gravel run the night before. For the first time on the trip, we actually got up at a decent hour and were ready to hit the road well before 10am. Thanks to Matt, his shower and his washing machine, we now had clean clothes to put on clean riders, and we were ready to put some serious miles on to make up for the day lost to Glacier. As Scott and I rounded up the last of our crap in the house, Dylan stepped out to check our tire pressures. Everything seemed normal until he got to my rear tire, which was running 20psi instead of the roughly 42psi it should have had. Sure enough, rolling my bike forward revealed some sort of twisted pair of nails or industrial staple that had punctured my tire in TWO places, barely 1/4" apart from one another. As I pulled out the offending sharp objects and began to wig out over the destruction of my brand new rear tire, Dylan pulled out the plug kit and went to work. We didn't think it would be possible to put two 3/8" wide mushroom plugs into holes that were 1/4" apart, but I'll be damned if that thing didn't hold air. For the record, when I checked the pressure for the final time 2000 miles later (on the following Saturday morning), it was still holding 41.5psi. Not too shabby, I'd say. Crisis averted, we loaded up the bikes and rolled down Hwy 35 around Flathead Lake. We ran into our first patch of rain as we approached the lake, a torrential downpour on the horizon that got uglier and uglier as we approached. We were hit with a few heavy drops as we skirted the storm, but we didn't bother to put on rain gear and turned south around the lake (and away from the rain) just as it started to become a concern. We met two guys from Froggy Canadia touring on sportbikes at a Safeway gas station in Polson. One of them was an idiot (like Scott) touring on an R1 because he evidently had some sort of anger issues with his legs, wrists and lower back and didn't want them to ever be usable again. He even had a jury-rigged Givi case on the back of his R1, just like Scott. Eventually we made our way south to Lolo, MT for lunch and got onto the much anticipated Hwy 12 over Lolo Pass in Idaho. The road was amazing and scenic, with very little traffic. It twisted along the banks of the Lochsa River, in which we stopped to stare at the overwhelming natural beauty and let Scott dip his obscenely white feet in the water. Burning daylight again and still far behind from our Glacier delay, we made another command decision and cut out Mt. Rainier and Mt. Saint Helens from this trip, so that we could still spend an evening relaxing in Portland and meeting up with some old friends and still make it home to the bay before November 2012. Once again we rode until dusk and ended up in Lewiston, ID right across the Snake River from Clarkson, Washington. Cute, huh? We ended up at the very well maintained (hot running water and showers FTW) Hells Gate State Park a few feet from the river. We paid and got our assigned campsites from the jailbait working behind the counter at the Lewis & Clark Discovery Center only to find sprinklers running in the space they assigned us. After a quick campsite swap, we set up our tents and headed into town for dinner. We grabbed food at a Mexican joint in Lewiston, then some firewood, snacks and alcohol at Albertsons, and headed back to the campground to drink and pass out. Route Map [gallery]
Day 6: Lolo Pass to the Gates of Hell

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: Wednesday the 30th brought us our second nugget of excitement, after the high-speed gravel run the night before. For the first time on the trip, we actually got up at a decent hour and were ready to hit the road well before 10am. Thanks to Matt, his shower and his washing machine, we now had clean clothes to put on clean riders, and we were ready to put some serious miles on to make up for the day lost to Glacier. As Scott and I rounded up the last of our crap in the house, Dylan stepped out to check our tire pressures. Everything seemed normal until he got to my rear tire, which was running 20psi instead of the roughly 42psi it should have had. Sure enough, rolling my bike forward revealed some sort of twisted pair of nails or industrial staple that had punctured my tire in TWO places, barely 1/4" apart from one another. As I pulled out the offending sharp objects and began to wig out over the destruction of my brand new rear tire, Dylan pulled out the plug kit and went to work. We didn't think it would be possible to put two 3/8" wide mushroom plugs into holes that were 1/4" apart, but I'll be damned if that thing didn't hold air. For the record, when I checked the pressure for the final time 2000 miles later (on the following Saturday morning), it was still holding 41.5psi. Not too shabby, I'd say. Crisis averted, we loaded up the bikes and rolled down Hwy 35 around Flathead Lake, we met two guys from Froggy Canadia touring on sportbikes at a Safeway gas station in Polson. One of them was an idiot (like Scott) touring on an R1 becuase he evidently had some sort of anger issues with his legs, wrists and lower back and didn't want them to ever be usable again. Eventually we made our way south to Lolo, MT for lunch and got onto the much anticipated Hwy 12 over Lolo Pass in Idaho. Route Map

Saint Helens from this trip, so that we could still spend an evening relaxing in Portland and meeting up with some old friends and still make it home to the bay before November 2012. Day 6: Lolo Pass to the Gates of Hell

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: In the morning, we rolled out of our Grinding Rock campsite and up Hwy 88 over Carson Pass, stopping for lunch in Kirkwood along the way. After lunch we rolled over the pass and down into Nevada, stopping for gas and refreshments outside Carson City, and taking a picture of the enormous moth that would be an omen for the insect storm to come. We didnâ€™t want to take 80 via Reno because 395 between Carson City and Reno are nothing but extreme heat, stop-and-go traffic and exhaust fumes. Instead, my route had us taking Hwy 50 from Carson City all the way out to Fallon, but on the fly I decided to cut up to 80 at Fernley, which turned out to be a good idea. Once we hit the 75mph speed limit on 80, we made very good time to Winnemucca. The ride was straight, flat, and hot as blazes as expected, but at least we were burning miles quickly. Still, we were burning daylight quickly and, as we took 95 up into eastern Oregon, we watched the sun setting to our left. At our next gas stop we had to make a command decision. We had some Hot Springs deeper in Oregon recommended by one friend, and a campground on the border recommended by another, but it was apparent that we weren't going to come close to making either by nightfall, so we opted to ride into the night and just get a motel room outside Boise to make up the time and mileage we lost on Friday night. Route Map [gallery]

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: Thursday's ride was fairly uneventful. Cutting out the two mountains in Washington, we rode down into Oregon via Hwy 12 and Walla Walla. Somewhere in Oregon we were stopped at a yet another road construction zone, but this time the cute blonde flagperson waved us up to the front of the pack and let us know that we had 10-15 minutes to take off our helmets, rest and chat with her before traffic would be let through. Eventually we met up with the Columbia River and stopped in Boardman, OR for some agonizingly slow Bozo Burgers (a.k.a. bacon cheeseburgers anywhere else in the universe). Scott got stuck behind a family of 2500 while trying to order his food, including one old man who wrote a personal check for $8.50 to cover his meal, and another old man who inquired if their chili was homemade before taking 10 minutes to haggle and waffle over sundae toppings. The ride along the Columbia River Gorge was beautiful, but probably would have been a lot more awe-inspiring had we not just come from some of the most beautiful stretches of road in the world. We eventually hit Portland and got stuck in a hefty traffic jam, which turned out to be the aftermath of a motorcycle accident. An older, small sportbike that was rattle-canned black was being loaded off the road. I thought it was an EX500, but Scott said it looks like a Hurricane. After some time gritting our teeth while not being able to lanesplit, we made it downtown and pulled off at a parking lot next to the convention center to call our respective friends. We were looking for a place to get a cheap motel room and be able to walk to food and booze. Scott's friend Josh suggested one quarter of town, my friend Jan suggested a different part of town, and Dylan's friend (with whom he was staying) lived in a completely different part of town. I ended up calling Thatch to break the tie, and Scott and I got a room at 10th and Burnside right across the street from Union Jack's (strip club), the Doug Fir (hipster bar), and next door to the Galaxy Restaurant & Lounge, complete with cheap drinks, decent Chinese food, and horrible karaoke. After a few beers at the Doug Fir (and breaking a half-full pint glass all over Josh's messenger bag about 8 seconds after meeting him), we moseyed across the street to meet Dylan and his friends Melissa and Erin at the Galaxy. A few more drinks, some pot stickers, and some atrocious singing chased us over to Union Jack's. Surprisingly, the drinks were bar-priced and not strip-club-priced, as is apparently the norm in Portland. Jan and Erin went their separate ways, and the rest of us spent a couple of hours drinking, talking and occasionally glancing at naked girls. A stripper lit Melissa's cigarette off her nipple (the stripper's, not Melissa's) using a paper match, some saliva and a little yankee ingenuity. Good times. Eventually Dylan and Melissa took off, then Josh took off, then Scott and I stumbled across the street to our motel room to pass the hell out. We're going to need to get back to Portland again. Route Map [gallery]
Day 7: Along the Columbia into Portland

table.column:

After a few beers at the Doug Fir (and breaking a half-full pint glass over Josh's messenger bag about 8 seconds after meeting him), we moseyed across the street to meet Dylan and his friends Melissa and Erin at the Galaxy. A stripper lit Melissa's cigarette off her nipple (the stripper's, not Melissa's) using a paper match, some saliva and a little yankee ingenuity.
Eventually Dylan and Melissa took off and Scott and I stumbled across the street to our motel to pass the hell out.

Somewhere in Oregon we were stopped at a yet another road construction zone, but this time the cute blonde flagperson waved us up to the front of the pack and let us know that we had 10-15 minutes to take off our helmets, rest and chat with her before traffic would be let through. Eventually we met up with the Columbia River and stopped in Boardman, OR for some agonizingly slow Bozo Burgers (a.k.a. bacon cheeseburgers anywhere else in the universe). Scott got stuck behind a family of 2500 while trying to order his food, including one old man who wrote a personal check for $8.50 to cover his meal, and another old man who inquired if their chili was homemade before taking 10 minutes to haggle and waffle over sundae toppings. The ride along the Columbia River Gorge was beautiful, but probably would have been a lot more awe-inspiring had we not just come from some of the most beautiful stretches of road in the world. We eventually hit Portland and got stuck in a hefty traffic jam, which turned out to be the aftermath of a motorcycle accident. An older, small sportbike that was rattlecanned black was being loaded off the road. I thought it was an EX500, but Scott said it looks like a Hurricane. After some time gritting our teeth while not being able to lanesplit, we made it downtown and pulled off at a parking lot next to the convention center to call our respective friends. We were looking for a place to get a cheap motel room and be able to walk to food and booze. Scott's friend Josh suggested one quarter of town, my friend Jan suggested a different part of town, and Dylan's friend (with whom he was staying) lived in a completely different part of town. I ended up calling Thatch to break the tie, and Scott and I got a room at 10th and Burnside right across the street from Union Jack's (strip club), the Doug Fir (hipster bar), and next door to the Galaxy Restaurant & Lounge, complete with cheap drinks, decent chinese food, and horrible karaoke. After a few beers at the Doug Fir (and breaking a half-full pint glass all over Josh's messenger bag about 8 seconds after meeting him), we moseyed across the street to meet Dylan and his friends Melissa and Erin at the Galaxy. A few more drinks, some pot stickers, and some atrocious singing chased us over to Union Jack's. Surprisingly, the drinks were bar-priced and not strip-club-priced, as is apparently the norm in Portland. Jan and Erin went their separate ways, and the rest of us spent a couple of hours drinking and talking. A stripper lit Melissa's cigarette off her nipple (the stripper's, not Melissa's) using a paper match, some saliva and a little yankee ingenuity. Good times. Eventually Dylan and Melissa took off, then Josh took off, then Scott and I stumbled across the street to our motel room to pass the hell out. We're going to need to get back to Portland again. Route Map [gallery]
Day 7: Along the Columbia River to Portland

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: Slightly hungover, we woke up to drizzle in Portland. Scott and I cleaned up and walked over to J & M's for breakfast, a place a few blocks away that Josh had recommended. We both had the J & M Plate, which consisted of two fried eggs on toasted english muffins, smothered in a ton of melted fontina cheese and crossed with two thick strips of bacon. Quite tasty and about 750,000 calories I'm sure. After breakfast and several cups of fine Portland coffee, we walked back to the hotel, packed up the bikes, and rolled over to Backspace, the gamer-centric cafe where Josh works. We got the grand tour, and Josh hooked us up with half a dozen excellent caffeinated beverages that would ensure piss-breaks every 6 miles, and a severe case of the shakes for most of the day. Dylan rolled up after a bit, and the three of us took off south on I-5 out of Portland. The drizzle had let up and appeared (from my iPhone weather radar thingy) that the rain was isolated, so we didn't bother with rain gear. Somewhere north of Salem, however, it started raining on us again and we pulled off at a gas station south of the city to fuel up and don our rain gear. Dylan stuck it out in just his leathers while Scott and I got geared up. After some Red Bull and trail mix, we were ready to continue on, but Scott couldn't find his Icon Ti-Max motorcycle gloves. He had evidently placed them on top of the gas pump he was using earlier, and some methed-out dick was kind enough to steal them in the ten minutes that had elapsed since we got gas. I loaned Scott my summer gloves because it wasn't very cold and I was wearing my gore-tex winter gloves anyway, and we looked up a Cycle Gear store in Eugene, OR before getting back on the freeway. Upon arriving in Eugene, Scott ended up picking up a cheap pair of crap leather gloves just to get him home, and I sat in the parking lot and stared at my motorcycle chain that kept stretching and stretching beyond belief. The chain wasn't even close to 10k miles old on this RK X-ring 530 chain (normally get an easy 20k+ out of each chain), but but this point the adjuster screws were backed all the way out and the chain was still drooping uncomfortably low. It was making a little noise here an there upon deceleration, but at this point it seemed FAR from unsafe, so I didn't get the slightest inkling to buy a new chain or at least a $4 masterlink to pop a few links out of the existing one to get me home. More on that later. We merged back onto 5 and cruised south, stopping for gas at a Chevron in Medford, OR. After getting off the freeway, Dylan's FZ6 would not kick into 1st gear, and we thought we might have another small disaster on our hands, but eventually Scott got it into gear and it was fine from then on. Go figure. We grabbed dinner at the Black Bear Diner in Medford around sunset, before getting back on the freeway. The portions were retarded huge, the staff all seemed a bit slow in the noggin, and three filthy, road-weary bikers were definitely out of place in this family chain restaurant. After dinner, we continued south and happily crossed into California (to higher speed limits and slightly less rabid highway patrol) in the dark. We made it down to Hwy 96 just north of Yreka and (very) slowly rode the pitch-black twisty road to our destination campground in the Klamath National Forest, all the while watching intently for deer, bears, moose, elk, elephants, rhino or whatever other manner of bloodthirsty beast might jump out in front of us and kill us all in a fiery gasoline-soaked inferno. Somehow, facing all that extreme peril, we made it the 12 miles to the campground safely. Scott coughed up the $10 for the site into the self-pay envelope, we set up camp quickly in the dark, and hit the sack when the insects started to get the best of us. Oh, and somewhere between Salem and Eugene my bike turned over 70,000 miles on the odometer. :) Route Map [gallery]

After breakfast and several cups of Portland coffee, we walked back to the hotel, packed up the bikes, and rolled over to Backspace, the gamer-centric cafe where Josh works. Dylan rolled up after a bit, and the three of us took off south on I-5 out of Portland. The drizzle had let up and appeared (from my iPhone weather radar thingy) that the rain was isolated, so we didn't bother with rain gear. Somewhere north of Salem, however, it started raining on us again and we pulled off at a gas station south of the city to fuel up and don our rain gear. Dylan stuck it out in just his leathers while Scott and I got geared up. After some Red Bull and trail mix, we were ready to continue on, but Scott couldn't find his Icon Ti-Max motorcycle gloves. He had evidently placed them on top of the gas pump he was using earlier, and some methed-out dick was kind enough to steal them in the ten minutes that had elapsed. I loaned Scott my summer gloves because I was wearing my goretex winter gloves anyway, and we looked up a Cycle Gear store in Eugene before getting back on the freeway. Scott ended up picking up a cheap pair of crap leather gloves just to get him home, and I sat in the parking lot and stared at my motorcycle chain that kept stretching and stretching beyond belief. The chain wasn't even close to 10k miles old (I normally get 20k+ out of each chain), but but this point the adjuster screws were backed all the way out and the chain was still drooping uncomfortably low. It was making some noise on deceleration, but at this point it seemed FAR from unsafe, so I didn't get the slightest inkling to buy a new chain or a tool to pop a few links out of the existing one to get me home. We got back on 5 and cruised south, stopping for gas at a Chevron in Medford. After getting off the freeway, Dylan's FZ6 would not kick into 1st gear, and we thought we might have another small disaster on our hands, but eventually Scott got it into gear and it was fine from then on. Go figure. We grabbed dinner at the Black Bear Diner in Medford around sunset, before getting back on the freeway. The portions were retarded huge, the staff all seemed a bit slow in the noggins, and the three of us were definitely out of place in this rural family restaurant. After dinner, we continued south and happily crossed into California (to higher speed limits and slightly less rabid highway patrol) in the dark. We made it down to Hwy 96 just north of Yreka and (very) slowly rode the pitch-black twisty road a few miles to our campground in the Klamath National Forest while watching intently for deer, bears, moose, elk, elephants, rhino or whatever other manner of beast might jump out in front of us and kill us all in a fiery gasoline-soaked inferno. Scott coughed up the $10 for the site into the self-pay envelope, we set up camp quickly in the dark, and hit the sack. Route Map

We made it down to Hwy 96 just north of Yreka and (very) slowly rode the pitch-black twisty road about 12 miles to our destination campground in the Klamath National Forest, all the while watching intently for deer, bears, moose, elk, elephants, rhino or whatever other manner of beast might jump out in front of us and kill us all in a fiery gasoline-soaked inferno. Scott coughed up the $10 for the site into the self-pay envelope, we set up camp quickly in the dark, and hit the sack when the insects started to get the best of us. Route Map [gallery]

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: Slightly hungover, we woke up to drizzle in Portland. Scott and I cleaned up and walked over to J & M's for breakfast, a place a few blocks away that Josh had recommended. We both had the J & M Plate, which consisted of two fried eggs on toasted english muffins, smothered in a ton of melted fontina cheese and crossed with two thick strips of bacon. Quite tasty and about 750,000 calories I'm sure. After breakfast and several cups of fine Portland coffee, we walked back to the hotel, packed up the bikes, and rolled over to Backspace, the gamer-centric cafe where Josh works. We got the grand tour, and Josh hooked us up with half a dozen excellent caffeinated beverages that would ensure piss-breaks every 6 miles, and a severe case of the shakes for most of the day. Dylan rolled up after a bit, and the three of us took off south on I-5 out of Portland. The drizzle had let up and appeared (from my iPhone weather radar thingy) that the rain was isolated, so we didn't bother with rain gear. Somewhere north of Salem, however, it started raining on us again and we pulled off at a gas station south of the city to fuel up and don our rain gear. Dylan stuck it out in just his leathers while Scott and I got geared up. After some Red Bull and trail mix, we were ready to continue on, but Scott couldn't find his Icon Ti-Max motorcycle gloves. He had evidently placed them on top of the gas pump he was using earlier, and some methed-out dick was kind enough to steal them in the ten minutes that had elapsed since we got gas. I loaned Scott my summer gloves because it wasn't very cold and I was wearing my gore-tex winter gloves anyway, and we looked up a Cycle Gear store in Eugene, OR before getting back on the freeway. Upon arriving in Eugene, Scott ended up picking up a cheap pair of crap leather gloves just to get him home, and I sat in the parking lot and stared at my motorcycle chain that kept stretching and stretching beyond belief. The chain wasn't even close to 10k miles old on this RK X-ring 530 chain (normally get an easy 20k+ out of each chain), but but this point the adjuster screws were backed all the way out and the chain was still drooping uncomfortably low. It was making a little noise here an there upon deceleration, but at this point it seemed FAR from unsafe, so I didn't get the slightest inkling to buy a new chain or at least a $4 masterlink to pop a few links out of the existing one to get me home. More on that later. We merged back onto 5 and cruised south, stopping for gas at a Chevron in Medford, OR. After getting off the freeway, Dylan's FZ6 would not kick into 1st gear, and we thought we might have another small disaster on our hands, but eventually Scott got it into gear and it was fine from then on. Go figure. We grabbed dinner at the Black Bear Diner in Medford around sunset, before getting back on the freeway. The portions were retarded huge, the staff all seemed a bit slow in the noggin, and three filthy, road-weary bikers were definitely out of place in this family chain restaurant. After dinner, we continued south and happily crossed into California (to higher speed limits and slightly less rabid highway patrol) in the dark. We made it down to Hwy 96 just north of Yreka and (very) slowly rode the pitch-black twisty road to our destination campground in the Klamath National Forest, all the while watching intently for deer, bears, moose, elk, elephants, rhino or whatever other manner of bloodthirsty beast might jump out in front of us and kill us all in a fiery gasoline-soaked inferno. Somehow, facing all that extreme peril, we made it the 12 miles to the campground safely. Scott coughed up the $10 for the site into the self-pay envelope, we set up camp quickly in the dark, and hit the sack when the insects started to get the best of us. Route Map [gallery]

Oh, and somewhere between Salem and Eugene my bike turned over 70,000 miles on the odometer. :) Route Map [gallery]

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: In the morning, we rolled out of our Grinding Rock campsite and up Hwy 88 over Carson Pass, stopping for lunch in Kirkwood along the way. After lunch we rolled over the pass and down into Nevada, stopping for gas and refreshments outside Carson City, and taking a picture of the enormous moth that would be an omen for the insect storm to come. We didnâ€™t want to take 80 via Reno because 395 between Carson City and Reno are nothing but extreme heat, stop-and-go traffic and exhaust fumes. Instead, my route had us taking Hwy 50 from Carson City all the way out to Fallon, but on the fly I decided to cut up to 80 at Fernley, which turned out to be a good idea. Once we hit the 75mph speed limit on 80, we made very good time to Winnemucca. The ride was straight, flat, and hot as blazes as expected, but at least we were burning miles quickly. Still, we were burning daylight quickly and, as we took 95 up into eastern Oregon, we watched the sun setting to our left. At our next gas stop we had to make a command decision. We had some Hot Springs deeper in Oregon recommended by one friend, and a campground on the border recommended by another, but it was apparent that we weren't going to come close to making either by nightfall, so we opted to ride into the night and just get a motel room outside Boise to make up the time and mileage we lost on Friday night. We rode well into the night, being as paranoid as possible about animals on the road, and sailing through an absolutely insane monsoon of insects along the Oregon/Idaho border. We stopped for dinner at a Shari's (the only thing that was open) on the outskirts of Boise and I went ahead and made the first potato joke of the week, commenting on how incredibly fresh Shari's waffle-cut fries were. We ended up settling in at a Motel 6 on the other end of Boise (by the airport) and sleeping like logs. Route Map [gallery]

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: We woke up and packed up camp under the already-sweltering sun. Before hitting the road, we decided to take some time riding around the park and exploring a few of the cool volcanic formations. We spent a while looking through some of the lava cones, and Scott and Dylan hiked to the top of one of the huge hills of black rock. On the way out, we asked the ranger at the gate about taking Hwy 93 up through eastern Idaho instead of taking I-15 up into Montana. He confirmed that 93 was more scenic, and told us it followed the Salmon River. From past experience, the three of us knew that any road that follows a river or creek is generally good, so we went with the new route. The first leg of 93 was flat and boring as expected--we were still in the agricultural (relative) lowlands of southern Idaho, but we had mountains in front of us and were looking forward to riding in them. We stopped for a ridiculously large lunch in Challis, ID where our AAA map said the scenic part of the road started. As promised, 93 from then on was beautiful. The roads were in excellent shape, and there was almost no one on the road. We hauled some fairly respectable ass. Once we crossed the border the speed limits went up significantly and so did our pace. With the glorious Montana speed limits, we were also met with a veritable ton of road construction, including quite a few stretches of nasty oiled gravel. We made good time between constructions zones, but were often held up for 10-15 minutes a pop when we hit another work site, and then a lot more time cruising over the gravel at 5mph. We cruised into Missoula, MT at dusk and stopped at the Walmart for some supplies, then decided to cut out to 93 via Hwy 200 and look for camping at Salmon Lake or Placid Lake. We ended up settling in at Salmon Lake, which had running water, hot showers and a firewood dispenser that resembled a gigantic, wooden coke machine. We put in 16 quarters and got a dry bundle of tiny logs that weighed about 3 ounces. Unfortunately, it took us four $4 bundles of balsa to realize that a neighboring (empty) campsite had a pile of huge, heavy logs that would probably burn all night, but we pilfered a few of them anyway to keep the fire going. Most campsites have an entry fee that covers 1 vehicle, and an additional vehicle fee for extra cars. Salmon Lake was $15 for the site, and appeared to be an additional $5 for every vehicle. Like we did at the campsite in Pine Grove, CA, we put cash for the site and 1.5 cars (6 wheels/3 bikes) in the self-pay envelope and waited to see if a ranger would hassle us in the morning. I was the first one up the next morning and, sure enough, a ranger rolled up like clockwork to (presumably) give us grief for not paying for 3 full vehicles. Instead, the ranger walked right up to me, handed me $8 back, and told me that the camp fee included all our vehicles. Gotta love Montana. Route Map [gallery]
Day 4: The Moon to Salmon Lake

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
We packed up our bikes in the Motel 6 parking lot and hit the road toward the Sawtooth Mountains. The ride up was beautiful and twisty, and the roads were fairly smooth and well maintained. There were plenty of cars and bikes on the road, but we weren't really held back and had plenty of opportunities to pass for the most part.
We stopped for lunch in Stanley, Idaho and got horrible service from a very personable waiter. Dylan and I got our food finally, but Scott's club sandwich sat on the counter for a good ten minutes while he watched us eat. Eventually, I got up and told another waitress I was going to take the food so we could eat and get out of dodge.
Getting geared up to leave, we spoke to a husband and wife touring on an FZ1 and SV650 respectively, as well as our first of many groups of helmetless riders on their way to Sturgis. Everyone was extremely friendly no matter what type of ride they were on.
The cruise south from Stanley was mostly flat farmland, and not nearly as interesting as I expected. We stopped in Sun Valley for gas and a rest, and eventually ended up at Craters on the Moon National Park before sunset. We acquired our campsite and set up our tents, then Scott and I flew into the nearest town (Arco, ID) for beer and snacks while Dylan finished setting up camp and explored a couple of the volcanic caves in the park.
Night fell, but the moon didn't come up until well into the wee hours of the morning. We passed a few hours drinking and playing dominoes while listning to Patton Oswalt and David Cross albums on my iPod. I won with 300 points, Dylan had 205 and Scott took (it) up the rear with 190.
[gallery]

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: We woke up fairly early on Saturday morning. We were having a great time on this trip, but 8 1/2 days of solid riding and sleeping on the ground is quite a bit--we were exhausted and ready to be home. I'd been waiting quite a while for the opportunity to ride Hwy 96 along the Klamath River. The north end starts just south of the Oregon border, so it's not an easy road to ride in just a weekend. The road that it meets on its southern end in Willow Creek (Hwy 299) follows the Trinity River and is one of my all-time favorite roads--I try to ride it at least two or three times a year. We left the campground around 9:15, and my chain was drooping lower than ever. Given that my adjuster screws had hit their limit a day or two prior, I didn't have much choice but to grin and bear it. The previous day's ride was almost entirely freeway riding down I-5 and it hadn't given me too much grief, probably due to the (relatively) constant speed and throttle of freeway riding compared to being on back roads. As we rolled out of the campground, the chain it was still making quite a clatter upon deceleration (when the slack bunches up it was slapping against the swingarm), so I asked Dylan to lead and I rode third behind Scott. With iffy acceleration and no engine breaking at my disposal, I really didn't want to rail through the hills. From our Saturday starting point just outside Yreka, was 152 miles to Willow Creek, an additional 47 or so to Eureka, followed by 270 back to San Francisco--at almost 500 miles, it was going to be a long day. Barely twenty or thirty miles into Hwy 96, we hit smoke. It was heavy smoke, and getting heavier by the mile. I didn't remember hearing about any major fires on this side of I-5 (most were in the Sierra foothills), but this was evidently a doozy. We rode through some manner of smoke for at least forty or fifty miles, and at its thickest I could barely see the river a few hundred feet below the road. My eyes were burning, my nose was burning, and my chain was not cooperating. Once the smoke started to clear a bit (about half way to Willow Creek), we stopped for a break at a gravel clearing along the river. We hydrated and micturated as needed, and I picked and inhaled a big handful of blackberries from the acres of bushes nearby...not necessarily in that order. At this point, my chain was misbehaving on deceleration and acceleration, and I was having a hell of a time feathering the clutch just to get over the smallest of hills. I still thought that, once we got to 101, I could limp her home and deal with the chain in the comfort of my own garage, with myriad tools and motorcycle shop parts counters at my disposal. We saddled back up and plodded on, but another 20 or 30 miles passed and my chain was getting exponentially worse with every passing mile. By now it was clattering constantly, at every speed and throttle position, and my concern level went from from "this seriously sucks" to "this is seriously dangerous" like a light switch. Dylan and Deeter were far ahead of me (as I was plodding along and feathering the clutch constantly at 30mph in a 55 zone that could be taken safely at 75). After I comitted the ultimate ego-suicide and waved a big, slow Harley past me, I think that Scott got an inkling that something was wrong and slowed down until he was right in front of me. I waved at him to pull over, parked the bike and got off. I put on one of the nitrex gloves I'd brought and tugged at the chain--sure enough, it was loose enough that it could have easily jumped the sprocket and destroyed my bike and/or me in the process. I decided that I'd be lucky to make it the last 30 or 40 miles to Willow Creek, let alone another 47 to Eureka, and that there was no way I'd make it back to San Francisco on this chain. Scott and I decided that he should run ahead and catch Dylan and send him back to escort me as far as I could go. Since Scott had a Blackberry (the internet phone, not the type I'd been picking earlier), he was going to race ahead to Eureka and start making phone calls to motorcycle shops he could find. I was looking for (in this order): [1] A shop with a service department that could swap my chain for me, [2] A gear/parts shop that could sell me a new chain with a clip-style master link I could mount myself in a parking lot, or [3] a clip-style master link, a hacksaw and a nail, so I could knock out a few links with Deeter's rubber tent-stake mallet and clip the shitty chain back together just to get home. At that point, I'd have been happy with some bailing wire or a handful of paperclips that I could string together and wrap around my sprockets. A few phone calls found a Honda dealership just south of us in Eureka that had a Western Powersports (a.k.a. generic crap) 530 chain in 120 links for $98. I didn't know what kind of master link it had, and I would have to find a way to kick out the 8 extra links, but I figured I'd deal with that at the shop. I left Deeter and Dylan to have lunch at the Lost Coast Brewing Co., hoping that I could get a new chain while they were eating and not cause much more of a delay than I already had. As I putted down 101 through downtown Eureka, feathering/burning out the clutch like I'd been doing for the past 200 miles, I passed a Kawasaki/KTM dealership on the left that I didn't find via Google earlier. I decided to stop and see what they had, just for good measure. I walked up to the parts counter and asked if they had any 530 O or X-ring chains on the shelf. The parts guy walked into the back room and came out with a DID O-Ring chain. "We have this one, how many links do you need?" "112" "This one's a 112." "Awesome. What kind of master link, clip or rivet?" He opened up the box and it was a rivet-style master link. I asked if they had a rivet press tool I could borrow to put it on my bike, and explained that I was 300 miles from home on the tail end of a 3,000 mile ride. He asked if I wanted to buy one but I already own one, so so he asked his service guy if he could put the chain on for me, which he promptly did in about 20 minutes. $169 out-the-door for parts and service, barely $20 more than I would have paid at home to put the chain on myself. I called Scott and made it back to Lost Coast while they were still waiting for the check. Perfect. Kick-ass. High-5. The three of us took off again down 101 and cruised about 50 miles to Miranda, CA to get gas. I sucked down a Red Bull and some of Dylan's copious trail mix, since I'd skipped lunch to get the new chain. Meanwhile, as we were parked up against the air/water station, Dylan said his bike was feeling a bit wonky and decided to check his tire pressure. Sure enough, he had a small puncture slowly leaking air out of his rear tire and his pressure was <20psi. I'll be damned if that bastard had the repair kit out, and the tire plugged and refilled in about three minutes--before Scott and I had even finished our beverages. I wish we had more of a story for that incident, but the tire went from flat to fixed and full in minutes, and we were back on the road again. Kind of anti-climactic, if you ask me. The rest of the ride home was uneventful and stress-free, thankfully. I'd forgotten how beautiful Hwy 101 was up through Humboldt and Mendocino counties. Nothing broke, and nothing was lost or stolen along the way. We stopped in Ukiah for gas and rest before our last 100 mile stretch home, and ended up chatting with a CHP officer about riding for a while. We complained about not being able to legally lanesplit past the traffic jam in Portland, and the officer said "you should have just done it, how would they even catch you?" Lulz. They caught my friend Jess just a couple weeks prior doing exactly that through Oregon, so evidently they have some practice at it. Scott broke off on the bridge for home in Daly City, and Dylan and I cruised to my apartment. Julius was fairly indifferent at my arrival, but Addie was absolutely insane. He meowed endlessly and followed me around the house, and stood outside the bathroom door and cried for 20 minutes while I showered and shaved. Adorable. Dylan and I got freshened up and walked down to DNA around 11pm to see friends, unwind and get mad crunk, yo. A couple of Chupa drinks later and we stumbled home and passed out. And the rest is history. Fin. Route Map [gallery]
Day 9: The Chain Will Keep Us Together

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: We woke up fairly early on Saturday morning. We were having a great time on this trip, but 8 1/2 days of solid riding and sleeping on the ground is quite a bit--we were exhausted and ready to be home. I'd been waiting quite a while for the opportunity to ride Hwy 96 along the Klamath River. The north end starts just south of the Oregon border, so it's not an easy road to ride in just a weekend. The road that it meets on its southern end in Willow Creek (Hwy 299) follows the Trinity River and is one of my all-time favorite roads--I try to ride it at least two or three times a year. We left the campground around 9:15, and my chain was drooping lower than ever. Given that my adjuster screws had hit their limit a day or two prior, I didn't have much choice but to grin and bear it. The previous day's ride was almost entirely freeway riding down I-5 and it hadn't given me too much grief, probably due to the (relatively) constant speed and throttle of freeway riding compared to being on back roads. As we rolled out of the campground, the chain it was still making quite a clatter upon deceleration (when the slack bunches up it was slapping the swingarm), so I asked Dylan to lead and I rode third behind Scott. With iffy acceleration and no engine breaking at my disposal, I really didn't want to rail through the hills. From our Saturday starting point just outside Yreka, was 152 miles to Willow Creek, an additional 47 or so to Eureka, followed by 270 back to San Francisco--at almost 500 miles it was going to be a long day. Barely twenty or thirty miles into Hwy 96, we hit smoke. It was heavy smoke, and getting heavier by the mile. I didn't remember hearing about any major fires on this side of I-5 (most were in the Sierras), but this was evidently a doozy. We rode through some manner of smoke for at least forty or fifty miles, and at its thickest I could barely see the river a few hundred feet below the road. My eyes were burning, my nose was burning, and my chain was not cooperating. Once the smoke started to clear a bit (about half way to Willow Creek), we stopped for a break at a gravel clearing along the river. We hydrated and micturated as needed, and I picked and inhaled a big handful of blackberries from the acres of bushes nearby...not necessarily in that order. At this point, my chain was misbehaving on deceleration and acceleration, and I was having a hell of a time feathering the clutch just to get over the smallest of hills. Still, I thought that once we got to 101 I could limp her home and deal with the chain in the comfort of my own garage, with myriad tools and motorcycle shop parts counters at my disposal. We saddled back up and plodded on, but another 20 or 30 miles passed and my chain was getting exponentially worse with every passing mile. By now it was clattering constantly, at every speed and throttle position, and my concern level went from from "this seriously sucks" to "this is seriously dangerous" like a light switch. Dylan and Deeter were far ahead of me (as I was plodding along and feathering the clutch constantly at 30mph in a 55 zone that could be taken safely at 75). After I comitted the ultimate ego-suicide and waved a big, slow Harley past me, I think that Scott got an inkling that something was wrong and slowed down until he was right in front of me. I waved at him to pull over, parked the bike and got off. I put on one of the nitrex gloves I'd brought and tugged at the chain--sure enough, it was loose enough that it could have easily jumped the sprocket and destroyed my bike and/or me in the process. I decided that I'd be lucky to make it the last 30 or 40 miles to Willow Creek, let alone another 47 to Eureka, and that there was no way I'd make it back to San Francisco on this chain. Scott and I decided that he should run ahead and catch Dylan and send him back to escort me as far as I could go. Since Scott had a Blackberry (the internet phone, not the type I'd been picking earlier), he was going to race ahead to Eureka and start making phone calls to motorcycle shops he could find. I was looking for (in this order): [1] A shop with a service department that could swap my chain for me, [2] A gear/parts shop that could sell me a new chain with a clip-style master link I could mount myself in a parking lot, or [3] a clip-style master link, a hacksaw and a nail, so I could knock out a few links with Deeter's rubber tent-stake mallet and clip the shitty chain back together just to get home. At that point, I'd have been happy with some bailing wire or a handful of paperclips that I could string together and wrap around my sprockets. A few phone calls found a Honda dealership just south of us in Eureka that had a Western Powersports (a.k.a. generic crap) 530 chain in 120 links for $98. I didn't know what kind of master link it had, and I would have to find a way to kick out the 8 extra links, but I figured I'd deal with that at the shop. I left Deeter and Dylan to have lunch at the Lost Coast Brewing Co., hoping that I could get a new chain while they were eating and not cause much more of a delay than I already had. As I putted down 101 through Eureka, feathering the clutch like I'd been doing for the past 200 miles, I passed a Kawasaki/KTM dealership on the left that I didn't find via Google earlier. I decided to stop and see what they had, just for good measure. I walked up to the parts counter and asked if they had any 530 O or X-ring chains on the shelf. The parts guy walked into the back room and came out with a DID O-Ring chain. "We have this one, how many links do you need?" "112" "This one's a 112." "Awesome. What kind of master link, clip or rivet?" He opened up the box and it was a rivet-style master link. I asked if they had a rivet-press tool I could borrow to put it on my bike, and explained that I was 300 miles from home on the tail end of a 3,000 ride. He asked if I wanted to buy one, but I told him that I already owned the $100 Motion-Pro chain tool set at home and really didn't need another one. Route Map
Day 9: The Chain Will Keep Us Together

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: We woke up fairly early on Saturday morning. We were having a great time on this trip, but 8 1/2 days of solid riding and sleeping on the ground is quite a bit--we were exhausted and ready to be home. I'd been waiting quite a while for the opportunity to ride Hwy 96 along the Klamath River. The north end starts just south of the Oregon border, so it's not an easy road to ride in just a weekend. The road that it meets on its southern end in Willow Creek (Hwy 299) follows the Trinity River and is one of my all-time favorite roads--I try to ride it at least two or three times a year. We left the campground around 9:15, and my chain was drooping lower than ever. Given that my adjuster screws had hit their limit a day or two prior, I didn't have much choice but to grin and bear it. As we rolled out of the campground, the chain it was still making quite a clatter upon deceleration (when the slack bunches up it was slapping the swingarm), so I asked Dylan to lead and I rode third behind Scott. With iffy acceleration and no engine breaking at my disposal, I really didn't want to rail through the hills.
