We rode through some manner of smoke for at least forty or fifty miles, and at its thickest I could barely see the river a few hundred feet below the road. My eyes were burning, my nose was burning, and my chain was not cooperating. Once the smoke started to clear a bit (about half way to Willow Creek), we stopped for a break at a gravel clearing along the river. We hydrated and micturated as needed, and I picked and inhaled a big handful of blackberries from the acres of bushes nearby...not necessarily in that order. At this point, my chain was misbehaving on deceleration and acceleration, and I was having a hell of a time feathering the clutch just to get over the smallest of hills. Still, I thought that once we got to 101 I could limp her home and deal with the chain in the comfort of my own garage, with myriad tools and motorcycle shop parts counters at my disposal. We saddled back up and plodded on, but another 20 or 30 miles passed and my chain was getting exponentially worse with every passing mile. By now it was clattering constantly, at every speed and throttle position, and my concern level went from from "this seriously sucks" to "this is seriously dangerous" like a light switch. Dylan and Deeter were far ahead of me (as I was plodding along and feathering the clutch constantly at 30mph in a 55 zone that could be taken safely at 75). After I comitted the ultimate ego-suicide and waved a big, slow Harley past me, I think that Scott got an inkling that something was wrong and slowed down until he was right in front of me. I waved at him to pull over, parked the bike and got off. I put on one of the nitrex gloves I'd brought and tugged at the chain--sure enough, it was loose enough that it could have easily jumped the sprocket and destroyed my bike and/or me in the process. I decided that I'd be lucky to make it the last 30 or 40 miles to Willow Creek, let alone another 47 to Eureka, and that there was no way I'd make it back to San Francisco on this chain. Scott and I decided that he should run ahead and catch Dylan and send him back to escort me as far as I could go. Since Scott had a Blackberry (the internet phone, not the type I'd been picking earlier), he was going to race ahead to Eureka and start making phone calls to motorcycle shops he could find. I was looking for (in this order): [1] A shop with a service department that could swap my chain for me, [2] A gear/parts shop that could sell me a new chain with a clip-style master link I could mount myself in a parking lot, or [3] a clip-style master link, a hacksaw and a nail, so I could knock out a few links with Deeter's rubber tent-stake mallet and clip the shitty chain back together just to get home. At that point, I'd have been happy with some bailing wire or a handful of paperclips that I could string together and wrap around my sprockets. A few phone calls found a Honda dealership just south of us in Eureka that had a Western Powersports (a.k.a. generic crap) 530 chain in 120 links for $98. I didn't know what kind of master link it had, and I would have to find a way to kick out the 8 extra links, but I figured I'd deal with that at the shop. I left Deeter and Dylan to have lunch at the Lost Coast Brewing Co., hoping that I could get a new chain while they were eating and not cause much more of a delay than I already had. As I putted down 101 through downtown Eureka, feathering/burning out the clutch like I'd been doing for the past 200 miles, I passed a Kawasaki/KTM dealership on the left that I didn't find via Google earlier. I decided to stop and see what they had, just for good measure. I walked up to the parts counter and asked if they had any 530 O or X-ring chains on the shelf. The parts guy walked into the back room and came out with a DID O-Ring chain. "We have this one, how many links do you need?" "112" "This one's a 112." "Awesome. What kind of master link, clip or rivet?" He opened up the box and it was a rivet-style master link. I asked if they had a rivet press tool I could borrow to put it on my bike, and explained that I was 300 miles from home on the tail end of a 3,000 ride. He asked if I wanted to buy one but I already own one, so so he asked his service guy if he could put the chain on for me, which he promptly did in about 20 minutes. $169 out-the-door for parts and service, barely $20 more than I would have paid at home to put the chain on myself. I called Scott and made it back to Lost Coast while they were still waiting for the check. Perfect. Kick-ass. High-5. The three of us took off again down 101 and cruised about 50 miles to Miranda, CA to get gas. I sucked down a Red Bull and some of Dylan's copious trail mix, since I'd skipped lunch to get a new chain. Meanwhile, as we were parked up against the air/water station, Dylan said his bike was feeling a bit wonky and decided to check his tire pressure. Sure enough, he had a small puncture slowly leaking air out of his rear tire and his pressure was <20psi. I'll be damned if that bastard had the repair kit out, and the tire plugged and refilled in about three minutes--before Scott and I had even finished our beverages. I wish we had more of a story for that incident, but the tire went from flat to fixed and full in minutes, and we were back on the road again. Kind of anti-climactic, if you ask me. The rest of the ride home was uneventful and stress-free, thankfully. I'd forgotten how beautiful Hwy 101 was up through Humboldt and Mendocino counties. Nothing broke, and nothing was lost or stolen along the way. We stopped in Ukiah for gas and rest before our last 100 mile stretch home, and ended up chatting with a CHP officer for a while about riding for a while. We complained about not being able to legally lanesplit past the traffic jam in Portland, and the officer said "you should have just done it, how would they even catch you?" Lulz. They caugt my friend Jess just a couple weeks prior doing exactly that through Oregon, so evidently they have some practice at it. Scott broke off on the bridge for home in Daly City, and Dylan and I cruised to my apartment. Julius was fairly indifferent at my arrival, but Addie was absolutely insane. He meowed endlessly and followed me around the house, and stood outside the bathroom door and cried for 20 minutes while I showered and shaved. Dylan and I got freshened up and walked down to DNA to see friends, unwind and get mad crunk. A couple of Chupa drinks later and we stumbled home and passed out. And the rest is history. Fin. Route Map
Day 9: The Chain Will Keep Us Together

Day 9: The Chain Will Keep Us Together

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
I'll continue to edit this list over the next few days as I think of things... Things I'd change about the route:
  • Cut over from Stanley, ID to Challis, ID on 75 instead of riding all the way down to 20. Craters on the Moon NP was very cool and worth seeing once, but southern Idaho in general is very flat and straight. The shortcut will save you 172 miles (230-58) of farmland and instead keep you in the twisties.
  • Hwy 2 around Glacier NP is beautiful, and should have been on the route from the getgo instead of an accidental find.
  • Ditto for Hwy 93 up the Salmon River. Epic.
Things I learned:
  • 400 miles per day is too ambitious, especially when setting up/taking down camp every day and stopping to see scenery and national parks. 250-350 would have been far more realistic, especially when hitting setbacks like road construction or bike/gear problems.
  • If you have even the slightest faint inkling that you're going to have a mechanical problem, nip it in the bud. No matter what the cost, it beats the hell out of breaking down later in BFE.
  • Don't buy RK chains. I've always run DID and my first RK chain ever (this one) died a nasty death at <10k. Teh suck.
  • Bullfrog clear gel sunscreen works quite well, goes on clean and dries quickly.
  • Montana has some of the best (Read: Highest) speed limits in the country, and some of the slowest god damned drivers. 55 in a 70 zone? Seriously?
  • Portland is a great town. The rest of Oregon can shove off into the ocean and take its speed limits and "Mini-Serve" gas stations with it.
Thing's I'm adding to my gear list:
  • Some lightweight (but strong) twine/rope to hang my lantern (and food in campsites that don't provide bear-proof containers).
  • Powdered Gatorade, because campground water tastes like ass and because Brawndo's got what plants crave.
  • Trail mix, cliff bars and beef jerky. That shit is expensive on the road.
  • One of those gaytarded head-lamp flashlights with the elastic strap that goes around your noggin. They look ridiculous, but it would have made setting up camp MUCH easier. Just don't wear it when you're not actually setting up a tent on the moon in total darkness.
  • A small spray bottle of leather cleaner/conditioner to get the bugs off my duds.
Tried and true suggestions for other riders on trips like this:
  • Go out an buy the tire plug kit and 12v compressor mentioned in this South Bay Riders thread. Seriously, go buy it NOW, don't even wait for your next trip. They're that good.
  • Get yourself a good camp pad to sleep on, preferably inflatable or self-inflating. They keep you comfortable and warm by keeping you off the ground. No brainer.
  • Apply ample Gold Bond powder to your arse, legs and nether regions before a long, hot ride. It seriously helps with chafing, "monkey butt" and general discomfort. Don't waste your money on "Monkey Butt Powder", Gold Bond does the job and is dirt cheap at any drug store.
  • If you can, carry at least one SPOT GPS Messenger in your group. It makes it far easier for friends and loved ones make sure you're still alive and kicking, ensures you can get emergency help even in the remotest parts of the world, and gives you a cool file full of waypoints to download and dream about when you get home. We had decent cell phone reception about 1% of the time on this trip, if that.
Complete Ride Route on Google Maps. Google Earth File from my SPOT messenger (Google Earth is free and cool). Total Miles: About 3,100 Average Speed In Oregon: 55mph Average Speed in Montana: 85mph MPG: Around 40 on the Hornet Gas Money: $325.29 Campgrounds: 5 nights running $10-25/pop for the group Hotels: 2 nights at around $75/pop for the group Incidentals: $169.20 for the new chain, about $200 in food and beverages (much of which I would have purchased at home anyway).

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: We woke up fairly early on Saturday morning. We were having a great time on this trip, but 8 1/2 days of solid riding and sleeping on the ground is quite a bit--we were exhausted and ready to be home. I'd been waiting quite a while for the opportunity to ride Hwy 96 along the Klamath River. The north end starts just south of the Oregon border, so it's not an easy road to ride in just a weekend. The road that it meets on its southern end in Willow Creek (Hwy 299) follows the Trinity River and is one of my all-time favorite roads--I try to ride it at least two or three times a year. We left the campground around 9:15, and my chain was drooping lower than ever. Given that my adjuster screws had hit their limit a day or two prior, I didn't have much choice but to grin and bear it. The previous day's ride was almost entirely freeway riding down I-5 and it hadn't given me too much grief, probably due to the (relatively) constant speed and throttle of freeway riding compared to being on back roads. As we rolled out of the campground, the chain it was still making quite a clatter upon deceleration (when the slack bunches up it was slapping against the swingarm), so I asked Dylan to lead and I rode third behind Scott. With iffy acceleration and no engine breaking at my disposal, I really didn't want to rail through the hills. From our Saturday starting point just outside Yreka, was 152 miles to Willow Creek, an additional 47 or so to Eureka, followed by 270 back to San Francisco--at almost 500 miles, it was going to be a long day. Barely twenty or thirty miles into Hwy 96, we hit smoke. It was heavy smoke, and getting heavier by the mile. I didn't remember hearing about any major fires on this side of I-5 (most were in the Sierra foothills), but this was evidently a doozy. We rode through some manner of smoke for at least forty or fifty miles, and at its thickest I could barely see the river a few hundred feet below the road. My eyes were burning, my nose was burning, and my chain was not cooperating. Once the smoke started to clear a bit (about half way to Willow Creek), we stopped for a break at a gravel clearing along the river. We hydrated and micturated as needed, and I picked and inhaled a big handful of blackberries from the acres of bushes nearby...not necessarily in that order. At this point, my chain was misbehaving on deceleration and acceleration, and I was having a hell of a time feathering the clutch just to get over the smallest of hills. I still thought that, once we got to 101, I could limp her home and deal with the chain in the comfort of my own garage, with myriad tools and motorcycle shop parts counters at my disposal. We saddled back up and plodded on, but another 20 or 30 miles passed and my chain was getting exponentially worse with every passing mile. By now it was clattering constantly, at every speed and throttle position, and my concern level went from from "this seriously sucks" to "this is seriously dangerous" like a light switch. Dylan and Deeter were far ahead of me (as I was plodding along and feathering the clutch constantly at 30mph in a 55 zone that could be taken safely at 75). After I comitted the ultimate ego-suicide and waved a big, slow Harley past me, I think that Scott got an inkling that something was wrong and slowed down until he was right in front of me. I waved at him to pull over, parked the bike and got off. I put on one of the nitrex gloves I'd brought and tugged at the chain--sure enough, it was loose enough that it could have easily jumped the sprocket and destroyed my bike and/or me in the process. I decided that I'd be lucky to make it the last 30 or 40 miles to Willow Creek, let alone another 47 to Eureka, and that there was no way I'd make it back to San Francisco on this chain. Scott and I decided that he should run ahead and catch Dylan and send him back to escort me as far as I could go. Since Scott had a Blackberry (the internet phone, not the type I'd been picking earlier), he was going to race ahead to Eureka and start making phone calls to motorcycle shops he could find. I was looking for (in this order): [1] A shop with a service department that could swap my chain for me, [2] A gear/parts shop that could sell me a new chain with a clip-style master link I could mount myself in a parking lot, or [3] a clip-style master link, a hacksaw and a nail, so I could knock out a few links with Deeter's rubber tent-stake mallet and clip the shitty chain back together just to get home. At that point, I'd have been happy with some bailing wire or a handful of paperclips that I could string together and wrap around my sprockets. A few phone calls found a Honda dealership just south of us in Eureka that had a Western Powersports (a.k.a. generic crap) 530 chain in 120 links for $98. I didn't know what kind of master link it had, and I would have to find a way to kick out the 8 extra links, but I figured I'd deal with that at the shop. I left Deeter and Dylan to have lunch at the Lost Coast Brewing Co., hoping that I could get a new chain while they were eating and not cause much more of a delay than I already had. As I putted down 101 through downtown Eureka, feathering/burning out the clutch like I'd been doing for the past 200 miles, I passed a Kawasaki/KTM dealership on the left that I didn't find via Google earlier. I decided to stop and see what they had, just for good measure. I walked up to the parts counter and asked if they had any 530 O or X-ring chains on the shelf. The parts guy walked into the back room and came out with a DID O-Ring chain. "We have this one, how many links do you need?" "112" "This one's a 112." "Awesome. What kind of master link, clip or rivet?" He opened up the box and it was a rivet-style master link. I asked if they had a rivet press tool I could borrow to put it on my bike, and explained that I was 300 miles from home on the tail end of a 3,000 mile ride. He asked if I wanted to buy one but I already own one, so so he asked his service guy if he could put the chain on for me, which he promptly did in about 20 minutes. $169 out-the-door for parts and service, barely $20 more than I would have paid at home to put the chain on myself. I called Scott and made it back to Lost Coast while they were still waiting for the check. Perfect. Kick-ass. High-5. The three of us took off again down 101 and cruised about 50 miles to Miranda, CA to get gas. I sucked down a Red Bull and some of Dylan's copious trail mix, since I'd skipped lunch to get the new chain. Meanwhile, as we were parked up against the air/water station, Dylan said his bike was feeling a bit wonky and decided to check his tire pressure. Sure enough, he had a small puncture slowly leaking air out of his rear tire and his pressure was <20psi. I'll be damned if that bastard had the repair kit out, and the tire plugged and refilled in about three minutes--before Scott and I had even finished our beverages. I wish we had more of a story for that incident, but the tire went from flat to fixed and full in minutes, and we were back on the road again. Kind of anti-climactic, if you ask me. The rest of the ride home was uneventful and stress-free, thankfully. I'd forgotten how beautiful Hwy 101 was up through Humboldt and Mendocino counties. Nothing broke, and nothing was lost or stolen along the way. We stopped in Ukiah for gas and rest before our last 100 mile stretch home, and ended up chatting with a CHP officer about riding for a while. We complained about not being able to legally lanesplit past the traffic jam in Portland, and the officer said "you should have just done it, how would they even catch you?" Lulz. They caught my friend Jess just a couple weeks prior doing exactly that through Oregon, so evidently they have some practice at it. Scott broke off on the bridge for home in Daly City, and Dylan and I cruised to my apartment. Julius was fairly indifferent at my arrival, but Addie was absolutely insane. He meowed endlessly and followed me around the house, and stood outside the bathroom door and cried for 20 minutes while I showered and shaved. Adorable. Dylan and I got freshened up and walked down to DNA around 11pm to see friends, unwind and get mad crunk, yo. A couple of Chupa drinks later and we stumbled home and passed out. And the rest is history. Fin. Route Map [gallery]
Day 9: The Chain Will Keep Us Together

Day 9: The Chain Will Keep Us Together

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: Thursday's ride was fairly uneventful. Cutting out the two mountains in Washington, we rode down into Oregon via Hwy 12 and Walla Walla. Somewhere in Oregon we were stopped at a yet another road construction zone, but this time the cute blonde flagperson waved us up to the front of the pack and let us know that we had 10-15 minutes to take off our helmets, rest and chat with her before traffic would be let through. Eventually we met up with the Columbia River and stopped in Boardman, OR for some agonizingly slow Bozo Burgers (a.k.a. bacon cheeseburgers anywhere else in the universe). Scott got stuck behind a family of 2500 while trying to order his food, including one old man who wrote a personal check for $8.50 to cover his meal, and another old man who inquired if their chili was homemade before taking 10 minutes to haggle and waffle over sundae toppings. The ride along the Columbia River Gorge was beautiful, but probably would have been a lot more awe-inspiring had we not just come from some of the most beautiful stretches of road in the world. We eventually hit Portland and got stuck in a hefty traffic jam, which turned out to be the aftermath of a motorcycle accident. An older, small sportbike that was rattlecanned black was being loaded off the road. I thought it was an EX500, but Scott said it looks like a Hurricane. After some time gritting our teeth while not being able to lanesplit, we made it downtown and pulled off at a parking lot next to the convention center to call our respective friends. We were looking for a place to get a cheap motel room and be able to walk to food and booze. Scott's friend Josh suggested one quarter of town, my friend Jan suggested a different part of town, and Dylan's friend (with whom he was staying) lived in a completely different part of town. I ended up calling Thatch to break the tie, and Scott and I got a room at 10th and Burnside right across the street from Union Jack's (strip club), the Doug Fir (hipster bar), and next door to the Galaxy Restaurant & Lounge, complete with cheap drinks, decent chinese food, and horrible karaoke. After a few beers at the Doug Fir (and breaking a half-full pint glass all over Josh's messenger bag about 8 seconds after meeting him), we moseyed across the street to meet Dylan and his friends Melissa and Erin at the Galaxy. A few more drinks, some pot stickers, and some atrocious singing chased us over to Union Jack's. Surprisingly, the drinks were bar-priced and not strip-club-priced, as is apparently the norm in Portland. Jan and Erin went their separate ways, and the rest of us spent a couple of hours drinking and talking. A stripper lit Melissa's cigarette off her nipple (the stripper's, not Melissa's) using a paper match, some saliva and a little yankee ingenuity. Good times. Eventually Dylan and Melissa took off, then Josh took off, then Scott and I stumbled across the street to our motel room to pass the hell out. We're going to need to get back to Portland again. Route Map [gallery]
Day 7: Along the Columbia into Portland

table.column: Thursday's ride was fairly uneventful. Cutting out the two mountains in Washington, we rode down into Oregon via Hwy 12 and Walla Walla. Somewhere in Oregon we were stopped at a yet another road construction zone, but this time the cute blonde flagperson waved us up to the front of the pack and let us know that we had 10-15 minutes to take off our helmets, rest and chat with her before traffic would be let through. Eventually we met up with the Columbia River and stopped in Boardman, OR for some agonizingly slow Bozo Burgers (a.k.a. bacon cheeseburgers anywhere else in the universe). Scott got stuck behind a family of 2500 while trying to order his food, including one old man who wrote a personal check for $8.50 to cover his meal, and another old man who inquired if their chili was homemade before taking 10 minutes to haggle and waffle over sundae toppings. The ride along the Columbia River Gorge was beautiful, but probably would have been a lot more awe-inspiring had we not just come from some of the most beautiful stretches of road in the world. We eventually hit Portland and got stuck in a hefty traffic jam, which turned out to be the aftermath of a motorcycle accident. An older, small sportbike that was rattlecanned black was being loaded off the road. I thought it was an EX500, but Scott said it looks like a Hurricane. After some time gritting our teeth while not being able to lanesplit, we made it downtown and pulled off at a parking lot next to the convention center to call our respective friends. We were looking for a place to get a cheap motel room and be able to walk to food and booze. Scott's friend Josh suggested one quarter of town, my friend Jan suggested a different part of town, and Dylan's friend (with whom he was staying) lived in a completely different part of town. I ended up calling Thatch to break the tie, and Scott and I got a room at 10th and Burnside right across the street from Union Jack's (strip club), the Doug Fir (hipster bar), and next door to the Galaxy Restaurant & Lounge, complete with cheap drinks, decent chinese food, and horrible karaoke. After a few beers at the Doug Fir (and breaking a half-full pint glass all over Josh's messenger bag about 8 seconds after meeting him), we moseyed across the street to meet Dylan and his friends Melissa and Erin at the Galaxy. A few more drinks, some pot stickers, and some atrocious singing chased us over to Union Jack's. Surprisingly, the drinks were bar-priced and not strip-club-priced, as is apparently the norm in Portland. Jan and Erin went their separate ways, and the rest of us spent a couple of hours drinking, talking and occasionally looking at naked girls. A stripper lit Melissa's cigarette off her nipple (the stripper's, not Melissa's) using a paper match, some saliva and a little yankee ingenuity. Good times. Eventually Dylan and Melissa took off, then Josh took off, then Scott and I stumbled across the street to our motel room to pass the hell out. We're going to need to get back to Portland again. Route Map [gallery]
Day 7: Along the Columbia into Portland

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
I'll continue to edit this list over the next few days as I think of things... Things I'd change about the route:
  • Cut over from Stanley, ID to Challis, ID instead of riding all the way down to 20. Craters on the Moon NP was very cool, but southern Idaho in general is very flat and straight.
  • Hwy 2 around Glacier NP is beautiful, and should have been on the route from the getgo instead of an accidental find. Ditto for Hwy 93 up the Salmon River. Epic.
Things I learned:
  • 400 miles per day is too ambitious, especially when setting up/taking down camp every day and stopping to see scenery and national parks. 250-350 would have been far more realistic, especially when hitting setbacks like road construction or bike/gear problems.
  • If you have even the slightest faint inkling that you're going to have a mechanical problem, nip it in the bud. No matter what the cost, it beats the hell out of breaking down later in BFE.
  • Don't buy RK chains. I've always run DID and my first RK chain ever (this one) died a nasty death at <10k. Teh suck.
  • Bullfrog clear gel sunscreen works quite well, goes on clean and dries quickly.
  • Montana has some of the best (Read: Highest) speed limits in the country, and some of the slowest god damned drivers.
Thing's I'm adding to my gear list:
  • Some lightweight (but strong) twine/rope to hang my lantern (and food in campsites that don't provide bear-proof containers).
  • Powdered Gatorade, because campground water tastes like ass and because Brawndo has what plants crave.
  • Trail mix, cliff bars and beef jerky. That shit is expensive on the road.
  • One of those gaytarded head-lamp flashlights with the elastic strap that goes around your noggin. They look ridiculous, but it would have made setting up camp MUCH easier.
Tried and true suggestions for other riders on trips like this:
  • Go out an buy the tire plug kit and 12v compressor mentioned in this South Bay Riders thread. Seriously, go buy it NOW, don't even wait for your next trip. They're that good.
  • Get yourself a good camp pad to sleep on, preferably inflatable or self-inflating. They keep you comfortable and warm by keeping you off the ground. No brainer.
  • If you can, carry at least one SPOT GPS Messenger in your group. It makes it far easier for friends and loved ones make sure you're still alive and kicking, ensures you can get emergency help even in the remotest parts of the world, and gives you a cool file full of waypoints to download and dream about when you get home.
  • Apply ample Gold Bond powder to your arse, legs and nether regions before a long, hot ride. It seriously helps with chafing, "monkey butt" and general discomfort. Don't waste your money on "Monkey Butt Powder", Gold Bond does the job and is dirt cheap at any drug store.

Complete Ride Route

Total Miles: About 3,100 Average Speed In Oregon: 55mph Average Speed in Montana: 85mph MPG: Around 40 on the Hornet Gas Money: About $330. Campgrounds: 5 nights running $10-25/pop for the group Hotels: 2 nights at around $75/pop for the group Incidentals: $170 for the new chain, about $200 in food and beverages (most of which I would have purchased at home anyway).

table.column: In the morning, we rolled out of our Grinding Rock campsite and up Hwy 88 over Carson Pass, stopping for lunch in Kirkwood along the way. After lunch we rolled over the pass and down into Nevada, stopping for gas and refreshments outside Carson City, and taking a picture of the enormous moth that would be an omen for the insect storm to come. We didnâ€™t want to take 80 via Reno because 395 between Carson City and Reno are nothing but extreme heat, stop-and-go traffic and exhaust fumes. Instead, my route had us taking Hwy 50 from Carson City all the way out to Fallon, but on the fly I decided to cut up to 80 at Fernley, which turned out to be a good idea. Once we hit the 75mph speed limit on 80, we made very good time to Winnemucca. The ride was straight, flat, and hot as blazes as expected, but at least we were burning miles quickly. Unfortunately, we were also burning daylight quickly and, as we took 95 up into eastern Oregon, we watched the sun quickly setting to our left. At our next gas stop we had to make a command decision. We had some Hot Springs deeper in Oregon recommended by one friend, and a campground on the border recommended by another, but it was apparent that we weren't going to come close to making either by nightfall, so we opted to ride into the night and just get a motel room outside Boise to make up the time and mileage we lost on Friday night. We rode well into the night, being as paranoid as possible about animals on the road, and sailing through an absolutely insane monsoon of insects along the Oregon/Idaho border. We stopped for dinner at a Shari's (the only thing that was open) on the outskirts of Boise and I went ahead and made the first potato joke of the week, commenting on how incredibly fresh Shari's waffle-cut fries were. We ended up settling in at a Motel 6 on the other end of Boise (by the airport) and sleeping like logs. Route Map [gallery]

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
I'll continue to edit this list over the next few days as I think of things... Things I'd change about the route:
  • Cut over from Stanley, ID to Challis, ID on 75 instead of riding all the way down to 20. Craters on the Moon NP was very cool and worth seeing once, but southern Idaho in general is very flat and straight. The shortcut will save you 172 miles (230-58) of farmland and instead keep you in the twisties.
  • Hwy 2 around Glacier NP is beautiful, and should have been on the route from the getgo instead of an accidental find.
  • Ditto for Hwy 93 up the Salmon River. Epic.
Things I learned:
  • 400 miles per day is too ambitious, especially when setting up/taking down camp every day and stopping to see scenery and national parks. 250-350 would have been far more realistic, especially when hitting setbacks like road construction or bike/gear problems.
  • If you have even the slightest faint inkling that you're going to have a mechanical problem, nip it in the bud. No matter what the cost, it beats the hell out of breaking down later in BFE.
  • Don't buy RK chains. I've always run DID and my first RK chain ever (this one) died a nasty death at <10k. Teh suck.
  • Bullfrog clear gel sunscreen works quite well, goes on clean and dries quickly.
  • Montana has some of the best (Read: Highest) speed limits in the country, and some of the slowest god damned drivers. 55 in a 70 zone? Seriously?
  • Portland is a great town. The rest of Oregon can shove off into the ocean and take its speed limits and "Mini-Serve" gas stations with it.
Thing's I'm adding to my gear list:
  • Some lightweight (but strong) twine/rope to hang my lantern (and food in campsites that don't provide bear-proof containers).
  • Powdered Gatorade, because campground water tastes like ass and because Brawndo's got what plants crave.
  • Trail mix, cliff bars and beef jerky. That shit is expensive on the road.
  • One of those gaytarded head-lamp flashlights with the elastic strap that goes around your noggin. They look ridiculous, but it would have made setting up camp MUCH easier. Just don't wear it when you're not actually setting up a tent on the moon in total darkness.
Tried and true suggestions for other riders on trips like this:
  • Go out an buy the tire plug kit and 12v compressor mentioned in this South Bay Riders thread. Seriously, go buy it NOW, don't even wait for your next trip. They're that good.
  • Get yourself a good camp pad to sleep on, preferably inflatable or self-inflating. They keep you comfortable and warm by keeping you off the ground. No brainer.
  • Apply ample Gold Bond powder to your arse, legs and nether regions before a long, hot ride. It seriously helps with chafing, "monkey butt" and general discomfort. Don't waste your money on "Monkey Butt Powder", Gold Bond does the job and is dirt cheap at any drug store.
  • If you can, carry at least one SPOT GPS Messenger in your group. It makes it far easier for friends and loved ones make sure you're still alive and kicking, ensures you can get emergency help even in the remotest parts of the world, and gives you a cool file full of waypoints to download and dream about when you get home. We had decent cell phone reception about 1% of the time on this trip, if that.
Complete Ride Route on Google Maps. Google Earth File from my SPOT messenger (Google Earth is free and cool). Total Miles: About 3,100 Average Speed In Oregon: 55mph Average Speed in Montana: 85mph MPG: Around 40 on the Hornet Gas Money: About $330. Campgrounds: 5 nights running $10-25/pop for the group Hotels: 2 nights at around $75/pop for the group Incidentals: $170 for the new chain, about $200 in food and beverages (much of which I would have purchased at home anyway).

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
My 919 forks are officially bent. Unofficially too. The bike is rideable for the time being, but they need to replaced as soon as possible.
I'm looking to upgrade to a pair of F4i forks, any year will do (as far as I can tell, all model years of the F4i are 43mm RSU cartridge forks). I don't need the triples, steering stem, wheel, axle, etc., just the forks alone as long as they are straight, don't leak and are in overall decent shape.
I also need an F4i front fender, but it's not as high a priority--I can find cheap fenders all over the place.
If you have a pair of forks you can part with, please to email ziad at wackyiraqi dawt kalm.

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: My police report from Volvo Fight 2008â„¢ finally arrived in the mail today, and I was found NOT at fault. The careless douche in the Volvo was from Davis, CA and the reporting officer's conclusion on page 8 cites the cause of the collision as an unsafe u-turn per CVC 22105. I was fairly sure this was exactly what the report would say, but it's still a huge relief to see it all in writing: SFPD Traffic Collision Report Now to contact his insurance company (AAA), get a damage estimate, and replace my bent forks.

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
Josh and I rolled over to the Chevron at 6th & Harrison to meet Henry and Jason around 8:30am. After some coffee and gas station snacks, we putted over to Oakland to meet Rhonda. From there the five of us had a flat, uneventful ride to beautiful Oakdale, where we stopped for gas and a break.

Joshâ€™s bike was bogging down at 7k RPM and he was worried that his charging system was shot again, so he picked up a multi-meter at the hardware store next to the gas station. The various voltage levels seemed fine, but he was blowing a ton of oil out of one gasket or another, so he topped off and we all continued on to Yosemite.

After paying our $10 entrance fees, we took a scenic but agonizingly slow ride through the park, stopping at Olmsted Point to gawk at the view. As we continued along Tioga Road and saw a large BARF group taking a break at Tuolumne meadows. We stopped to chat for a few minutes, then continued on to Hawthorne.

We took our last gas stop in Lee Vining, then proceeded to scream across highway 167, a 60 mile stretch of one the straightest, flattest, middle-of-nowherest roads Iâ€™ve ever been on. Once we got a few miles in, I rolled on the throttle and screamed passed some of the BARF riders ahead of us, slowing a bit as I crested the occasional hill and staring intently at the rare oncoming cars in the distance to try and avoid the minute chance an epic speeding ticket.

Cruising along at triple-digits, eventually another bike popped up in my mirrors and soon Jason blew by me on his Daytona 675. Shortly thereafter, another headlight appeared in my mirror, and Josh caught up to me on his 25 year-old, oil-spewing rat bike. We all slowed down back down to the speed limit and regrouped as we approached the booming metropolis of Hawthorne, Nevada.

We rolled into the El Capitan Lodge to check in. I checked in and gave up our non-smoking room to a BARFer in front of me who looked like he was going to blow a gasket when he was told that all they had was smoking rooms left despite his reservation. It was no huge deal to us, and our smoking room turned out to smell far less like a rancid ashtray than some of the non-smoking rooms our friends had.

After a quick change, we headed over to the casino and met up with some friends. Melissa bought us a round of beers, and then a group of us headed across the street for pizza where Rhonda was nice enough to buy us all dinner, and then over to Joeâ€™s Tavern for a thousand 50Â¢ Budweisers. Dave rode up as we were eating outside, and Jon called from Merced and eventually rolled into town around 10:30pm.

Memo to Self: Bring own pool cue on next trip to Hawthorne. I hate to be the guy showing up with a pool cue because I'm not good enough to, but I hate square tips even more.

Average speed in Yosemite NP: 45mph Top speed in Yosemite NP: 45mph Average speed on Hwy 167: 110mph Top speed on Hwy 167: 131mph (~145 indicated, 131.0 on GPS)

Rally Thread on BARF

Friday Route Map

[gallery]
Day 1: BARF Rally ride to Hawthorne, NV

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: After some Advil and coffee to counteract the 1000 beers from the night before, a few of us congregated and decided to break from the official BARF destination schedule and ride to Bodie State Historical Park on Saturday instead of on the way home Sunday. That way, we could take our time and spend most of the day milling around the old ghost town instead of worrying about having to get home. Rather than burning more daylight with a long meal in town, our group (now Jon, Josh, Steve and Henry and me) rode to Lee Vining for a quick bite at the much-hyped Mobile station restaurant. Josh and Jon both ordered food, and were not impressed. I just had a handful of trail mix and one of those Toll House cookie ice cream sandwiches. After food, we rolled up 395 to 270 and rode the 9 miles on pavement, and an additional 3 miles on hard, rutted dirt road to the ghost town. Somewhere along the bumpy dirt stretch my water bottle flew off the back of my bike, but Steve stopped and picked it up for me. We left most of our gear on our bikes and spent a few hours walking around the ghost town. The buildings and furniture, appliances and trinkets inside of them were fascinating and we all took scores of photos as we walked around what's left of the town. When we were done in Bodie, we decided to ride up to a barbecue joint in Walker, but decided instead to go for barbecue in Lee Vining because Jon's rear tire was in its death throes and really didn't need the extra 100 miles. Steve graciously bought us all dinner at Bodie Mike's in Lee Vining, and we all screamed back across 167 to Hawthorne for another 1000 dirt-cheap piss beers. When we arrived back at the hotel we realized that we'd completely spaced on the big group dinner for the evening, but we ended up hanging out, shooting pool, and drinking with a gaggle of BARF folks at Joe's after they were done eating. Oh, on the ride out on 167 in the morning I broke my land-speed record on the Hornet (set a couple of years ago on Highway 25 at 137mph) with 138.6 mph on the GPS, or a little over 150 indicated on the speedometer. Saturday Route Map [gallery]

After paying our $10 entrance fees, we took a scenic but very slow ride through the park, stopping at Olmsted Point to stare at the view. As we continued along Tioga Road and saw a large BARF group taking a break at Tuolumne meadows. We stopped to chat for a few minutes, then continued on to Hawthorne.

We took our last gas stop in Lee Vining, then proceeded to scream across highway 167, a 60 mile stretch of one the straightest, flattest, middle-of-nowherest roads Iâ€™ve ever been on. Once we got a few miles in, I rolled on the throttle and screamed passed some of the BARF riders ahead of us, slowing a bit as I crested the occasional hill and staring intently at the rare oncoming cars in the distance to try and avoid the minute chance an epic speeding ticket.

Cruising along at triple-digits, eventually another bike popped up in my mirrors and soon Jason blew by me on his Daytona 675. Shortly thereafter, another headlight appeared in my mirror, and Josh caught up to me on his 25 year-old, oil-spewing rat. We all slowed down back down to the speed limit and regrouped as we approached the booming metropolis of Hawthorne, Nevada.

We rolled into the El Capitan Lodge to check in. I checked in and gave up our non-smoking room to a BARFer in front of me who looked like he was going to blow a gasket when he was told that all they had was smoking rooms left despite his reservation. It was no huge deal to us, and our smoking room turned out to smell far less like a rancid ashtray than some of the non-smoking rooms our friends had.

After a quick change, we headed over to the casino and met up with some friends. Melissa bought us a round of beers, and then a group of us headed acover to Joeâ€™s Tavern across the street for a thousand 50 cent Budweisers.

Average speed in Yosemite NP: 45mph

Top speed in Yosemite NP: 45mph

Average speed on Hwy 167: 110mph

Top speed on Hwy 167: 131mph (~150 indicated, 131.0 on GPS)

Friday Route Map
Day 1: BARF Rally ride to Hawthorne, NV

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
Josh and I rolled over to the Chevron at 6th & Harrison to meet Henry and Jason around 8:30am. After some coffee and gas station snacks, we rolled over to Oakland to meet Rhonda. From there we had a flat, uneventful ride to beautiful Oakdale, where we stopped for gas and a break.

Joshâ€™s bike was bogging down and he was worried that his charging system was shot again, so he picked up a multi-meter at the hardware store next to the gas station. The various voltage levels seemed fine, but he was blowing a ton of oil out of one gasket or another, so he topped off and we all continued on to Yosemite.

After paying our $10 entrance fees, we took a scenic but very slow ride through the park, stopping at Olmsted Point to stare at the view. As we continued along Tioga Road and saw a large BARF group taking a break at Tuolumne meadows. We stopped to chat for a few minutes, then continued on to Hawthorne.

We took our last gas stop in Lee Vining, then proceeded to scream across highway 167, a 60 mile stretch of one the straightest, flattest, middle-of-nowherest roads Iâ€™ve ever been on. Once we got a few miles in, I rolled on the throttle and screamed passed some of the BARF riders ahead of us, slowing a bit as I crested the occasional hill and staring intently at the rare oncoming cars in the distance to try and avoid the minute chance an epic speeding ticket.

Cruising along at triple-digits, eventually another bike popped up in my mirrors and soon Jason blew by me on his Daytona 675. Shortly thereafter, another headlight appeared in my mirror, and Josh caught up to me on his 25 year-old, oil-spewing rat. We all slowed down back down to the speed limit and regrouped as we approached the booming metropolis of Hawthorne, Nevada.

We rolled into the El Capitan Lodge to check in. I checked in and gave up our non-smoking room to a BARFer in front of me who looked like he was going to blow a gasket when he was told that all they had was smoking rooms left despite his reservation. It was no huge deal to us, and our smoking room turned out to smell far less like a rancid ashtray than some of the non-smoking rooms our friends had.

After a quick change, we headed over to the casino and met up with some friends. Melissa bought us a round of beers, and then a group of us headed across the street for pizza, and then over to Joeâ€™s Tavern for a thousand 50Â¢ Budweisers. Dave rolled up as we were eating, and Jon called from Merced and eventually rolled into town around 10:30pm.

Average speed in Yosemite NP: 45mph Top speed in Yosemite NP: 45mph Average speed on Hwy 167: 110mph Top speed on Hwy 167: 131mph (~150 indicated, 131.0 on GPS)

Friday Route Map
Day 1: BARF Rally ride to Hawthorne, NV

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: After some Advil and coffee to counteract the 1000 beers from the night before, a few of us congregated and decided to break from the official BARF destination schedule and ride to Bodie State Historical Park on Saturday instead of on the way home Sunday. That way, we could take our time and spend most of the day milling around the old ghost town instead of worrying about having to get home. Rather than burning more daylight with a long meal in town, our group (now Jon, Josh, Steve and Henry and me) rode to Lee Vining for a quick bite at the much-hyped Mobile station restaurant. After food, we rolled up 395 to 270 and rode the 9 miles on pavement, and an additional 3 miles on hard, rutted dirt road to the ghost town. Somewhere along the bumpy dirt stretch my water bottle flew off the back of my bike, but Steve stopped and picked it up for me. We left most of our gear on our bikes and spent a few hours walking around the ghost town. The buildings and furniture, appliances and trinkets inside of them were fascinating and we all took scores of photos as we walked around what's left of the town. When we were done in Bodie, we decided to ride up to a barbecue joint in Walker, but decided instead to go for barbecue in Lee Vining because Jon's rear tire was in its death throes and really didn't need the extra 100 miles. Steve graciously bought us all dinner at Bodie Mike's in Lee Vining, and we all screamed back across 167 to Hawthorne for another night of dirt-cheap piss beer. When we arrived back at the hotel we realized that we'd completely spaced on the big group dinner for the evening, but we ended up hanging out, shooting pool, and drinking with a gaggle of BARF folks at Joe's after they were done eating. Saturday Route Map [gallery]

Saturday Route Map [gallery]

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: I woke up a bit hungover at 8am, took a shower, got dressed in street clothes, and then put in my earphones and promptly fell back asleep until about 10am. Jon and Josh eventually got up, and we packed up and checked out at the crack of noon. We ate a thoroughly disappointing breakfast of Huevos Rancheros (evidently Spanish for "fried egg with crap salsa thrown on") at Jack's Mexican-American food in Hawthorne, then gassed up and hit the road. I got my Huevos Rancheros and ate it despite the fact that I'd actually ordered Huevos con Chorizo (evidently Spanish for "also Huevos Rancheros"). Jon's rear tire was toast (though still no cords showing through) and Josh's bike was still vomiting up a ton of oil, but they kept an eye on both as we rode back home. We took 167 to 395, then rode up to 108 over the Sierras. Sonora Pass was stunning--the scenery was gorgeous and the road was amazingly twisty and well groomed. We had to pass quite a few idiots in SUVs and RVs, but made decent time over the mountains to stop in Dardanelle for a break. There we ran into Frank from BARF/SBR who was on a large group ride that was unrelated to the rally. We took off a few seconds after they all did, but immediately got a helmet-tap from the riders ahead of us. I was leading our small group of three, and we were putting along at about 40mph (in a 55mph zone) behind another couple of riders. Eventually I got fed up and passed them, only to approach another five or six riders from their group also putting along at 40-45mph. A few hundred feet in front of them was a Highway Patrol SUV (hence the helmet-taps) tailgating a solo rider from their big group who appeared to be doing well under the speed limit. After several agonizingly slow miles, the solo rider pulled off the road at a campground and let the CHP unit pass him. We continued on behind the slow-moving group for a few more miles, not knowing how far ahead the CHP had gone. Jon got tired of waiting and blew past all of us, only to almost catch up to the CHP truck a few turns ahead. He slowed down to the speed limit and waved me past him, and the cop finally pulled off the road at the next town, after what seemed like twelve days behind him. The rest of the ride was fairly uneventful, and blazing hot through the valley. Jon broke off towards 5 in Oakdale, and Josh broke off in Oakland to see a friend. I got home, showered, grilled a couple of pork chops out of the freezer, and passed the hell out with my cats on top of me. Sunday Route Map Google Earth file from my SPOT GPS Messenger [gallery]

table.column:
http://bayarearidersforum.com/forums/showthread.php?t=242213 Josh and I rolled over to the Chevron at 6th & Harrison to meet Henry and Jason around 8:30am. After some coffee and gas station snacks, we rolled over to Oakland to meet Rhonda. From there we had a flat, uneventful ride to beautiful Oakdale, where we stopped for gas and a break.

Joshâ€™s bike was bogging down and he was worried that his charging system was shot again, so he picked up a multi-meter at the hardware store next to the gas station. The various voltage levels seemed fine, but he was blowing a ton of oil out of one gasket or another, so he topped off and we all continued on to Yosemite.

After paying our $10 entrance fees, we took a scenic but very slow ride through the park, stopping at Olmsted Point to stare at the view. As we continued along Tioga Road and saw a large BARF group taking a break at Tuolumne meadows. We stopped to chat for a few minutes, then continued on to Hawthorne.

We took our last gas stop in Lee Vining, then proceeded to scream across highway 167, a 60 mile stretch of one the straightest, flattest, middle-of-nowherest roads Iâ€™ve ever been on. Once we got a few miles in, I rolled on the throttle and screamed passed some of the BARF riders ahead of us, slowing a bit as I crested the occasional hill and staring intently at the rare oncoming cars in the distance to try and avoid the minute chance an epic speeding ticket.

Cruising along at triple-digits, eventually another bike popped up in my mirrors and soon Jason blew by me on his Daytona 675. Shortly thereafter, another headlight appeared in my mirror, and Josh caught up to me on his 25 year-old, oil-spewing rat. We all slowed down back down to the speed limit and regrouped as we approached the booming metropolis of Hawthorne, Nevada.

We rolled into the El Capitan Lodge to check in. I checked in and gave up our non-smoking room to a BARFer in front of me who looked like he was going to blow a gasket when he was told that all they had was smoking rooms left despite his reservation. It was no huge deal to us, and our smoking room turned out to smell far less like a rancid ashtray than some of the non-smoking rooms our friends had.

After a quick change, we headed over to the casino and met up with some friends. Melissa bought us a round of beers, and then a group of us headed across the street for pizza, and then over to Joeâ€™s Tavern for a thousand 50Â¢ Budweisers. Dave rolled up as we were eating, and Jon called from Merced and eventually rolled into town around 10:30pm.

Day 1: BARF Rally ride to Hawthorne, NV

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: After some Advil and coffee to counteract the 1000 beers from the night before, a few of us congregated and decided to break from the official BARF destination schedule and ride to Bodie State Historical Park on Saturday instead of on the way home Sunday. That way, we could take our time and spend most of the day milling around the old ghost town instead of worrying about having to get home. Rather than burning more daylight with a long meal in town, our group (now Jon, Josh, Steve and Henry and me) rode to Lee Vining for a quick bite at the much-hyped Mobile station restaurant. After food, we rolled up 395 to 270 and rode the 9 miles on pavement, and an additional 3 miles on hard, rutted dirt road to the ghost town. Somewhere along the bumpy dirt stretch my water bottle flew off the back of my bike, but Steve stopped and picked it up for me. We left most of our gear on our bikes and spent a few hours walking around the ghost town. The buildings and furniture, appliances and trinkets inside of them were fascinating and we all took scores of photos as we walked around what's left of the town. When we were done in Bodie, we decided to ride up to a barbecue joint in Walker, but decided instead to go for barbecue in Lee Vining because Jon's rear tire was in its death throes and really didn't need the extra 100 miles. Steve graciously bought us all dinner at Bodie Mike's in Lee Vining, and we all screamed back across 167 to Hawthorne for another 1000 dirt-cheap piss beers. When we arrived back at the hotel we realized that we'd completely spaced on the big group dinner for the evening, but we ended up hanging out, shooting pool, and drinking with a gaggle of BARF folks at Joe's after they were done eating. Oh, on the ride out on 167 in the morning I broke my land-speed record on the Hornet (set a couple of years ago on Highway 25 at 137mph) with 138.6 mph on the GPS, or a little over 150 indicated on the speedometer. Saturday Route Map [gallery]

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: I woke up a bit hungover at 8am, took a shower, got dressed in street clothes, and then put in my earphones and promptly fell back asleep until about 10am. Jon and Josh eventually got up, and we packed up and checked out at the crack of noon. We ate a thoroughly disappointing breakfast of Huevos Rancheros (evidently Spanish for "fried egg with crap salsa thrown on") at Jack's Mexican-American food in Hawthorne, then gassed up and hit the road. I got my Huevos Rancheros and ate it despite the fact that I'd actually ordered Huevos con Chorizo (evidently Spanish for "also Huevos Rancheros"). Jon's rear tire was toast (though still no cords showing through) and Josh's bike was still vomiting up a ton of oil, but they kept an eye on both as we rode back home. We took 167 to 395, then rode up to 108 over the Sierras. Sonora Pass was stunning--the scenery was gorgeous and the road was amazingly twisty and well groomed. We had to pass quite a few idiots in SUVs and RVs, but made decent time over the mountains to stop in Dardanelle for a break. There we ran into Frank from BARF/SBR who was on a large group ride that was unrelated to the rally. We took off a few seconds after they all did, but immediately got a helmet-tap from the riders ahead of us. I was leading our small group of three, and we were putting along at about 40mph (in a 55mph zone) behind another couple of riders. Eventually I got fed up and passed them, only to approach another five or six riders from their group also putting along at 40-45mph. A few hundred feet in front of them was a Highway Patrol SUV (hence the helmet-taps) tailgating a solo rider from their big group who appeared to be doing well under the speed limit. After several agonizingly slow miles, the solo rider pulled off the road at a campground and let the CHP unit pass him. We continued on behind the slow-moving group for a few more miles, not knowing how far ahead the CHP had gone. Jon got tired of waiting and blew past all of us, only to almost catch up to the CHP truck a few turns ahead. He slowed down to the speed limit and waved me past him, and the cop finally pulled off the road at the next town, after what seemed like twelve days behind him. The rest of the ride was fairly uneventful, and blazing hot through the valley. Jon broke off towards 5 in Oakdale, and Josh broke off in Oakland to see a friend. I got home, showered, grilled a couple of pork chops out of the freezer, and passed the hell out with my cats on top of me. Sunday Route Map Google Earth file from my SPOT GPS Messenger [gallery]

Article:Hells Angels touched by a mentor:/c/a/2008/09/15/MNVG12UGSR.DTL
Article:Hells Angels touched by a mentor:/c/a/2008/09/15/MNVG12UGSR.DTL

Hells Angels touched by a mentor

Matthew B. Stannard, Chronicle Staff Writer

Tuesday, September 16, 2008

More...
(09-15) 18:41 PDT -- Papa's final ride was a Viking funeral, his body borne to his final resting place by a river of chrome and thunder. Mark "Papa" Guardado, 46, was killed Sept. 2 outside a Mission District bar. At the time, he was president of the Frisco Hells Angels, royalty of the outlaw biker realm. He was shot to death, police say, by Christopher Ablett, 37, of Modesto, a member of the rival Mongols Motorcycle Club, whose bad blood with the Hells Angels goes back in history. Ablett is still being sought. But there was little talk of the Mongols as the Hells Angels gathered to remember Guardado at a vigil Sunday night and funeral Monday morning; little more than a passing, irritated reference to a Sonoma County prosecutor who had charges pending against Guardado stemming from a bar fight and who called him a dangerous gang member with an assault conviction on his record. Instead, those gathered remembered their Guardado, the friend or surrogate father, the man who many said bought them their first Harley-Davidson - or helped them get the job they needed to buy their own. "To me, and everyone that knew him, he was the epitome of Hells Angels," said Richard Goldammer, who rode from his home in British Columbia to honor the man he called his mentor. "He set an example for a lot of people, being straight up, honest and respectful to everyone," he said. "People form their own opinion about our club ... we are who we are. We stand in our own social circle." It is a circle with many intersecting rings that pulled together in Daly City for what many hailed as an event of unprecedented scale. Well over 1,000 motorcyclists gathered at Duggan's Serra Mortuary for the two-day memorial: Hells Angels chapters from Alaska to Maine, from Rhode Island to Hawaii, and from overseas - Norway, Germany, England, Australia, Italy and more. And not just Hells Angels showed up. Duggan's parking lot hosted a collection of motorcycle clubs rarely seen outside events in Hollister or Sturgis, S.D., - the Mecca and Medina of biker culture. Top Hatters and Henchmen, Vampires and Devil Dolls, representatives of large groups and small, they all slapped leather-clad shoulders and shared tears and tales of Papa Guadardo, or just exchanged stories from the road. Overall, despite the continuous rumble of motorcycles arriving and departing, the farewell to Guardado was as quiet and thoughtful as any funeral. Police expected and reported few incidents. A few beers and flasks were raised in the assemblage, but most drank water and soda or coffee as they waited and mourned. As the vigil began Sunday evening, mourners packed the main room at Duggan's and several smaller rooms, where they watched on closed circuit television. Huge, grizzled men wept as one of their number sang Willie Nelson's "Angel Flying Too Close to the Ground," accompanying himself on saxophone. An emotional pastor described Guardado as a friendly, supportive man, a good son, father, uncle and godfather whose independent streak began with a runaway attempt as a 5-year-old. He described Guardado's good acts - donning a Santa hat to take gifts to children in the hospital at Christmas, or to children whose fathers were in prison; taking food left over after club events to feed the homeless. "When you do right they never remember," the pastor said. "When you do wrong they never forget." The vigil ended with Guardado's goddaughter singing Alicia Keys' "Prelude to a Kiss." "It's a long long way to heaven But I gotta get there Can you send me an angel to guide me?" The caravan escorting Guardado's coffin to Colma's Cypress Lawn Cemetery on Monday morning went by way of San Francisco's Mission District, a river of thunder that flowed through the urban canyons for more than an hour. The caravan didn't stop for signals; it set its own speed limit. Some onlookers waved, some took pictures, some pressed hands to ears and waited for the end. And for a brief period on Interstate 280, as police halted all other freeway traffic, the mourners took over the roads. They buried Papa not too far from where former Daly City Hells Angels President Harry "The Horse" Flamburis is buried with his motorcycle. The Frisco Hells Angels and a sea of red-and-white-clad others formed a close group around Guardado's grave. A few words were spoken as a biker on the outskirts cranked Metallica's somber ode "Nothing Else Matters." The ceremony over, the Angels picked up shovels and buried their leader. Then they returned to their motorcycles and roared away.

E-mail Matthew B. Stannard at mstannard@sfchronicle.com.

http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/09/16/BAVG12UGSR.DTL

This article appeared on page B - 1 of the SanÂ FranciscoÂ Chronicle

And not just Hells Angels showed up. Duggan's parking lot hosted a collection of motorcycle clubs rarely seen outside events in Hollister or Sturgis, S.D., - the Mecca and Medina of biker culture. Overall, despite the continuous rumble of motorcycles arriving and departing, the farewell to Guardado was as quiet and thoughtful as any funeral. Police expected and reported few incidents. A few beers and flasks were raised in the assemblage, but most drank water and soda or coffee as they waited and mourned. As the vigil began Sunday evening, mourners packed the main room at Duggan's and several smaller rooms, where they watched on closed circuit television. Huge, grizzled men wept as one of their number sang Willie Nelson's "Angel Flying Too Close to the Ground," accompanying himself on saxophone. An emotional pastor described Guardado as a friendly, supportive man, a good son, father, uncle and godfather whose independent streak began with a runaway attempt as a 5-year-old. He described Guardado's good acts - donning a Santa hat to take gifts to children in the hospital at Christmas, or to children whose fathers were in prison; taking food left over after club events to feed the homeless. "When you do right they never remember," the pastor said. "When you do wrong they never forget." The vigil ended with Guardado's goddaughter singing Alicia Keys' "Prelude to a Kiss." "It's a long long way to heaven But I gotta get there Can you send me an angel to guide me?" The caravan escorting Guardado's coffin to Colma's Cypress Lawn Cemetery on Monday morning went by way of San Francisco's Mission District, a river of thunder that flowed through the urban canyons for more than an hour. The caravan didn't stop for signals; it set its own speed limit. Some onlookers waved, some took pictures, some pressed hands to ears and waited for the end. And for a brief period on Interstate 280, as police halted all other freeway traffic, the mourners took over the roads. They buried Papa not too far from where former Daly City Hells Angels President Harry "The Horse" Flamburis is buried with his motorcycle. The Frisco Hells Angels and a sea of red-and-white-clad others formed a close group around Guardado's grave. A few words were spoken as a biker on the outskirts cranked Metallica's somber ode "Nothing Else Matters." The ceremony over, the Angels picked up shovels and buried their leader. Then they returned to their motorcycles and roared away.

E-mail Matthew B. Stannard at mstannard@sfchronicle.com.

Article:Hells Angels touched by a mentor:/c/a/2008/09/15/MNVG12UGSR.DTL

Hells Angels touched by a mentor

Matthew B. Stannard, Chronicle Staff Writer

Tuesday, September 16, 2008

More...
(09-15) 18:41 PDT -- Papa's final ride was a Viking funeral, his body borne to his final resting place by a river of chrome and thunder. Mark "Papa" Guardado, 46, was killed Sept. 2 outside a Mission District bar. At the time, he was president of the Frisco Hells Angels, royalty of the outlaw biker realm. He was shot to death, police say, by Christopher Ablett, 37, of Modesto, a member of the rival Mongols Motorcycle Club, whose bad blood with the Hells Angels goes back in history. Ablett is still being sought. But there was little talk of the Mongols as the Hells Angels gathered to remember Guardado at a vigil Sunday night and funeral Monday morning; little more than a passing, irritated reference to a Sonoma County prosecutor who had charges pending against Guardado stemming from a bar fight and who called him a dangerous gang member with an assault conviction on his record. Instead, those gathered remembered their Guardado, the friend or surrogate father, the man who many said bought them their first Harley-Davidson - or helped them get the job they needed to buy their own. "To me, and everyone that knew him, he was the epitome of Hells Angels," said Richard Goldammer, who rode from his home in British Columbia to honor the man he called his mentor. "He set an example for a lot of people, being straight up, honest and respectful to everyone," he said. "People form their own opinion about our club ... we are who we are. We stand in our own social circle." It is a circle with many intersecting rings that pulled together in Daly City for what many hailed as an event of unprecedented scale. Well over 1,000 motorcyclists gathered at Duggan's Serra Mortuary for the two-day memorial: Hells Angels chapters from Alaska to Maine, from Rhode Island to Hawaii, and from overseas - Norway, Germany, England, Australia, Italy and more. And not just Hells Angels showed up. Duggan's parking lot hosted a collection of motorcycle clubs rarely seen outside events in Hollister or Sturgis, S.D., - the Mecca and Medina of biker culture. Top Hatters and Henchmen, Vampires and Devil Dolls, representatives of large groups and small, they all slapped leather-clad shoulders and shared tears and tales of Papa Guadardo, or just exchanged stories from the road. Overall, despite the continuous rumble of motorcycles arriving and departing, the farewell to Guardado was as quiet and thoughtful as any funeral. Police expected and reported few incidents. A few beers and flasks were raised in the assemblage, but most drank water and soda or coffee as they waited and mourned. As the vigil began Sunday evening, mourners packed the main room at Duggan's and several smaller rooms, where they watched on closed circuit television. Huge, grizzled men wept as one of their number sang Willie Nelson's "Angel Flying Too Close to the Ground," accompanying himself on saxophone. An emotional pastor described Guardado as a friendly, supportive man, a good son, father, uncle and godfather whose independent streak began with a runaway attempt as a 5-year-old. He described Guardado's good acts - donning a Santa hat to take gifts to children in the hospital at Christmas, or to children whose fathers were in prison; taking food left over after club events to feed the homeless. "When you do right they never remember," the pastor said. "When you do wrong they never forget." The vigil ended with Guardado's goddaughter singing Alicia Keys' "Prelude to a Kiss." "It's a long long way to heaven But I gotta get there Can you send me an angel to guide me?" The caravan escorting Guardado's coffin to Colma's Cypress Lawn Cemetery on Monday morning went by way of San Francisco's Mission District, a river of thunder that flowed through the urban canyons for more than an hour. The caravan didn't stop for signals; it set its own speed limit. Some onlookers waved, some took pictures, some pressed hands to ears and waited for the end. And for a brief period on Interstate 280, as police halted all other freeway traffic, the mourners took over the roads. They buried Papa not too far from where former Daly City Hells Angels President Harry "The Horse" Flamburis is buried with his motorcycle. The Frisco Hells Angels and a sea of red-and-white-clad others formed a close group around Guardado's grave. A few words were spoken as a biker on the outskirts cranked Metallica's somber ode "Nothing Else Matters." The ceremony over, the Angels picked up shovels and buried their leader. Then they returned to their motorcycles and roared away.

E-mail Matthew B. Stannard at mstannard@sfchronicle.com.

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column: From his March 4, 2009 Podcast, one-time star of radio and TV and one-time motorcyclist Adam Corolla ruminates on BAMBI bikers, "thank you" waves, loud pipes and novelty helmets. For the record, I agree with him on just about every point, and I always wave thanks when a car lets me through and it's safe to do so (a good 90% of the time). Adam Corolla on Bikers MP3 (NSFW Audio)

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
Last night on my commute home up 101 between Belmont and San Francisco, I rolled up on (and was subsequently stuck behind) one of the worst lane-splitters I've ever seen. He exhibited all the signs of a newbie with little to no experience lane splitting in heavy commute traffic: He was agonizingly slow. He continually jumped over the line between the #1 to #2 lanes (something that'll earn a rider a fat ticket). He was reluctant to split past cars when he had plenty of space. He braked hard and often, then accelerated through dangerous gaps in traffic, where cars tend to jump lanes and hit motorcycles with no warning. At this point, you're probably wondering why I didn't just move two lanes over and pass the guy and speed off into the split like any normal rider would do when confronted with a rolling road-hazard like that. That's the rub--the rider was a CHP officer, on-duty, riding his R1150-RTP like a 4 year-old on his first bicycle. The best part of the whole debacle? I arrived home, and stepped off my bike to this message on my phone from a friend who evidently saw us both pass from his car:
"Re: Chp Really don't know how to split lanes do they??? lol Sent via Facebook Mobile"
Why yes, I did lol.
Hi. You fail at motorcycles. Please ride a desk instead.

table.column: Last night on my commute home up 101 between Belmont and San Francisco, I rolled up on and was subsequently stuck behind one of the worst lane-splitters I've ever seen. He exhibited all the signs of a newbie with little to no experience splitting in heavy commute traffic: He was agonizingly slow, and continually jumped over the line from the #1 to #2 lane (something that'll earn a rider a fat ticket). He was reluctant to split past cars when he had plenty of space. He braked hard and often, then accelerated through dangerous gaps in traffic, where cars tend to jump lanes and hit motorcycles with no warning. He lingered between cars, allowing them plenty of time to weave in their lanes and pinch him. For the 15 or so miles that I was stuck behind him, I was fully expecting him to crash at any moment. So why didn't IÂ  just move two lanes over and pass the guy and speed off into the split like any normal rider would do when confronted with a rolling road-hazard like that? That's the rub--the rider was a CHP officer, on-duty, riding his RT1100-RTP police bike like a 4 year-old who desperately needed training wheels.
Hi. You fail at motorcycles. Please ride a desk instead.

At this point, you're probably wondering why I didn't just move two lanes over and pass the guy and speed off into the split like any normal rider would do when confronted with a rolling road-hazard like that. That's the rub--the rider was a CHP officer, on-duty, riding his R1150-RTP police bike like a 4 year-old on his first bicycle. The best part of the whole debacle? I arrived home, and stepped off my bike to this message on my phone from a friend who evidently saw us both pass from his car:
"Re: Chp Really don't know how to split lanes do they??? lol Sent via Facebook Mobile"
Why yes, I did LOL.
Hi. You fail at motorcycles. Please ride a desk instead.

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
Last night on my commute home up 101 between Belmont and San Francisco, I rolled up on (and was subsequently stuck behind) one of the worst lane-splitters I've ever seen. He exhibited all the signs of a newbie with little to no experience lane splitting in heavy commute traffic: He was agonizingly slow. He continually jumped over the line from the #1 to #2 lane (something that'll earn a rider a fat ticket) He was reluctant to split past cars when he had plenty of space. He braked hard and often, then accelerated through dangerous gaps in traffic, where cars tend to jump lanes and hit motorcycles with no warning). At this point, you're probably wondering why I didn't just move two lanes over and pass the guy and speed off into the split like any normal rider would do when confronted with a rolling road-hazard like that. table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
Lane-sharing (lane-splitting, filtering, white-lining, etc.) is currently legal in one and only state in the US: California. It's a crying shame, really, as it's not only legal but exceedingly common in just about every other country on the planet. But it's so dangerous! Right?! Not exactly, no. According to the Hurt Report, the reigning bible of motorcycle crash statistics, the risk to a rider of being hit while lane-sharing is actually less than the risk of being hit while sitting in traffic with the drooling, four-wheeled masses. This is largely due to the relatively good chance of being rear-ended in stop-and-go traffic, coupled with the increased attention levels required of riders to lane-share. With those initial few facts out of the way, and before I get into any specific tips on lane-sharing, let me first fire out this big disclaimer:
I'm neither a teacher nor a certified instructor. I'm not an expert, per se; I don't have any fancy certificates on my wall and I've never taught any sort of organized class on motorcycling. What I'll be sharing are my opinions--information, tips and techniques that I've picked up from my own experiences and those I've learned from other riders over the yearsâ€”nothing more. I have been riding motorcycles religiously for about ten years and commuting daily up and down the all-too-congested Highway 101 in the San Francisco Bay Area for about five of those years, day or night, rain or shine. As one might imagine, I have more lane-sharing miles under my belt than many riders have total miles. Still, you should take everything I say here with a large grain of salt, as you should the advice of any random motorcyclist who tries to dole it out. Don't ever do anything on a motorcycle with which you're not 110% comfortable. Don't ride above your abilities. Don't believe everything you read on the internet. If it seems like a bad idea, it probably is. Never stop learning. Your mileage may vary. Void where prohibited by law. Need not be present to win. Donâ€™t chop down cherry trees.
Over the coming weeks and months, I'll be posting some thoughts (and pretty pictures!) that will hopefully help you become a safer, more confident lane-sharererer-erer. If you don't currently split lanes, hopefully I'll be able to give you a tiny bit of knowledge and help you start slowly, carefully and safely, to live in a world without traffic jams.
Lane Sharing I: The Very Basics, and a Disclaimer

According to the Hurt Report, the bible of motorcycling safety statistics, the risk of a rider being hit while lane-sharing is actually slightly less than the risk of while sitting in stop-and-go traffic.
