table.column:
Lane-sharing (lane-splitting, filtering, white-lining, etc.) is currently legal in one and only state in the US: California. It's a crying shame, really, as it's not only legal but exceedingly common in just about every other country on the planet. But it's so dangerous! Right?! Not exactly, no. According to the Hurt Report, the reigning bible of motorcycle crash statistics, the risk to a rider of being hit while lane-sharing is actually less than the risk of being hit while sitting in traffic with the drooling, four-wheeled masses. This is largely due to the relatively good chance of being rear-ended in stop-and-go traffic, coupled with the increased attention levels required of riders to lane-share. With those initial few facts out of the way, and before I get into any specific tips on lane-sharing, let me first fire out this big disclaimer:
I'm neither a teacher nor a certified instructor. I'm not an expert, per se; I don't have any fancy certificates on my wall and I've never taught any sort of organized class on motorcycling. What I'll be sharing are my opinions--information, tips and techniques that I've picked up from my own experiences and those I've learned from other riders over the yearsâ€”nothing more. I have been riding motorcycles religiously for about ten years and commuting daily up and down the all-too-congested Highway 101 in the San Francisco Bay Area for about five of those years, day or night, rain or shine. As one might imagine, I have more lane-sharing miles under my belt than many riders have total miles. Still, you should take everything I say here with a large grain of salt, as you should the advice of any random motorcyclist who tries to dole it out. Don't ever do anything on a motorcycle with which you're not 110% comfortable. Don't ride above your abilities. Don't believe everything you read on the internet. If it seems like a bad idea, it probably is. Never stop learning. Your mileage may vary. Void where prohibited by law. Need not be present to win. Donâ€™t chop down cherry trees.
Over the coming weeks and months, I'll be posting some thoughts (and pretty pictures!) that will hopefully help you become a safer, more confident lane-sharererer-erer. If you don't currently split lanes, hopefully I'll be able to give you a tiny bit of knowledge and help you start slowly, carefully and safely, to live in a world without traffic jams.
Lane Sharing I: The Very Basics, and a Disclaimer

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
According to the California Highway Patrol website, "lane splitting by motorcycles is permissible but must be done in a safe and prudent manner."

Terms like "safe" and "prudent" are rather vague, but most experienced motorcyclists will tell you that a top speed of roughly 35-40mph and a speed differential (or delta, the difference in speed between you and the rest of traffic) of 10-15 mph is what they generally live by when lane-sharing.

That's not to say that you can never safely overtake a car at 50mph, or that it's always safe to overtake a car at 15mph. There are countless variables involved in making a decision to safely split past an automobile: weather, road conditions, and time of day are three of the biggest. As the one and only person responsible for your safety on a motorcycle, ultimately it's up to you to judge whether or not it's safe to split, and at what speed you're going to be safe doing it for a given set of conditions.

Most new riders start out a bit slow and wobbly, even more so when they're lane-sharing, so it's important to keep your speed down at first. Eventually, you'll get faster and more smooth, but there's a limit to everything. There is a maximum speed at which no rider can react fast enough to being cut off--at that point your maximum speed has little do with your skill level, and much to do with the amount of risk you're willing to accept. In other words, splitting through 5mph traffic at 70 is a game of chance, and relying on lady luck instead of your skills is never a good idea on a motorcycle.

Lane-sharing on a freeway is generally done in the very right portion of the #1 lane (the far left "fast" lane). Splitting other lanes is not illegal, but the farther right you move the more likely and often cars are going to changing lanes to enter and exit the highway. Splitting between the #2 and #3 lanes is generally considered bad form, because those those drivers in the #2 lane who see you coming and are considerate enough to move left out of your way will be moving right into the path of any motorcyclists in the more typical #1 lane. I'll talk more about this when I eventually get to the topic of passing slower riders in the split.

Occasionally, you'll need to cross into the #2 lane to sneak around a particularly wide vehicle or one that that's positioned in the right half of the #1 lane, but constantly jumping back and forth between lanes is sloppy, dangerous, and illegal. In addition to pissing off all the drivers around you, you're likely to get popped with an unsafe lane change ticket (CVC 21658) by your friendly neighborhood CHP officer.
Lane Sharing II: Speed and Lane Position

table.name: wp_cpwgp4_posts
table.column:
Last night on my commute home up 101 between Belmont and San Francisco, I rolled up on (and was subsequently stuck behind) one of the worst lane-splitters I've ever seen. He exhibited all the signs of a newbie with little to no experience lane splitting in heavy commute traffic: He was agonizingly slow. He continually jumped over the line between the #1 to #2 lanes (something that'll earn a rider a fat ticket). He was reluctant to split past cars when he had plenty of space. He braked hard and often, then accelerated through dangerous gaps in traffic, where cars tend to jump lanes and hit motorcycles with no warning. At this point, you're probably wondering why I didn't just move two lanes over and pass the guy and speed off into the split like any normal rider would do when confronted with a rolling road-hazard like that. That's the rub--the rider was a CHP officer, on-duty, riding his R1150-RTP like a 4 year-old on his first bicycle. The best part of the whole debacle? I arrived home, and stepped off my bike to this message on my phone from a friend who evidently saw us both pass from his car:
"Re: Chp Really don't know how to split lanes do they??? lol Sent via Facebook Mobile"
Why yes, I did lol.
Hi. You fail at motorcycles. Please ride a desk instead.
